analyzed: utpatti nāśa kārī hi buddhimān dṛśyate kvacid
translated: For, somewhere an intelligent [agent] is seen to be the cause of origination and destruction.

analyzed: tad dṛṣṭāntena sarvatra kartā kim nā anumīyate
translated: By that example, why is an agent not inferred everywhere?

original: āgamānugṛhītā tu mānameṣānumāpitu // / / //🔽āgamānugrahābhāve na tarkaḥ syāt pratiṣṭhitaḥ /
analyzed: āgama anugṛhītā tu māna meṣa anumāpi tu  āgama anugraha abhāve na tarkaḥ syāt pratiṣṭhitaḥ
translated: But inference is to be inferred by one favored by scripture.🔽If there is no favor of scripture, inference would not be established.

analyzed: akṣaja āgama mūlasya syāt eva asya pratiṣṭhitiḥ
translated: If it has as its basis perception and scripture, then it would have a basis.

analyzed: anyathā asya apratiṣṭhā ca sva vācā vyāhatā eva hi
translated: Otherwise, its lack of basis is indeed contradicted by its own words.

analyzed: na ca śiṣya agṛhīta tvam nirīśa ādīśavādinaḥ
translated: And the non-acceptance by disciples is not of the non-Īśa [school] of the Īśa [Upaniṣads].

analyzed: atas  tat mano kuruta ityādeḥ asataḥ manasaḥ janiḥ
translated: Therefore, here the agency of the remaining jīva [souls] and so on is being denied.🔽The origin of the non-existent mind is prohibited by statements such as that mind creates [in the Upaniṣads].

analyzed: nivāritā tu pūrvatra hi akasmāt iti tat vinā
translated: But in the previous [verse], the origin of the mind from something else is prohibited by the words without cause.

analyzed: asataḥ viśva jananam āśaṅkayā atra
translated: The possibility of the origination of the universe from the non-existent is here denied out of apprehension.

analyzed: prāpakam vākya mātram tu parihāraḥ viśeṣitaḥ
translated: But the mere statement that it is the cause is specified as the avoidance.

analyzed: kvacid jīva akṛtam dṛṣṭvā cetanāt eva ca akṛtam
translated: In some cases, having seen that which is done by the individual soul, and that which is done only by the conscious one,

analyzed: tadvat evā anumānī atra vastu tvāt kriyate śruteḥ
translated: in the same way, here, on account of being an object, inference is made from the Vedic text.

analyzed: na anyat anyatvam āpannam kvacid dṛṣṭam kathañcana
translated: Nowhere has anything ever been seen to attain a different nature in any way.

original: ato jīvasya na brahmabhāvaḥ syāddhi kadācana // / / //🔽kvacid bhinnatayā dṛṣṭaṃ tadabhinnatayā katham /
analyzed: atas jīvasya na brahma bhāvaḥ syāt hi kadācana  kvacid bhinna tayā dṛṣṭam tat abhinna tayā katham
translated: Therefore, the individual soul would never at any time attain the nature of Brahman.

original: dṛśyenno dṛṣṭapūrvaṃ hi tādṛśaṃ na ca dṛśyate // / / //🔽bhoktṛtvāpattita iti yanmataṃ tat kuto hariḥ /
analyzed: dṛśyet no dṛṣṭa pūrvam hi tādṛśam na ca dṛśyate  bhoktṛ tva āpattitaḥ iti yat matam tat kutas hariḥ
translated: How can that which is seen as different in some places be seen as non-different? For such a thing has never been seen before.

analyzed: bhoktṛ āpatteḥ iti prāha katham ca tad ananyatā
translated: If it is thought that Hari is the enjoyer because of the attainment of the state of the enjoyer, how is that non-difference stated?

analyzed: jagataḥ tu avikāra tve ukta nyāyena sādhite
translated: When the changelessness of the world has been established by the stated reasoning,

analyzed: svatantra kāraṇa anyatvam tena hi atra
translated: the difference from an independent cause is denied by that here.

original: dravyaṃ karma ca kālaśca svabhāvaścetanā dhṛtiḥ /
analyzed: dravyam karma ca kālaḥ ca svabhāvaḥ cetanā dhṛtiḥ
translated: Substance, action, time, nature, consciousness, and support -

analyzed: yad prasādāt ime santi na santi yad upekṣayā
translated: by whose grace these exist, and by whose neglect they do not exist,

original: iti śrutestadvaśasya bhāvo na para ityataḥ // / / //
analyzed: iti śruteḥ tad vaśasya bhāvaḥ na paraḥ iti atas
translated: Thus, because of this Vedic statement, the existence of that [world] is not dependent on another.

original: śakto 'pi hyanyathākartuṃ svecchāniyamato hariḥ /🔽kāraṇairniyataireva karotīdaṃ jagat sadā // / / //
analyzed: śaktaḥ hi anyathā kartum sva icchā niyamataḥ hariḥ  kāraṇaiḥ niyataiḥ eva karoti idam jagat sadā
translated: Even though able, Hari, due to the restriction of His own will, does not create in a different way.🔽He always creates this world only through fixed causes.

analyzed: nitya bhedaḥ nimittena hi upādānena tu dvayam
translated: The eternal difference is due to the instrumental cause, but the two are due to the material cause.

analyzed: asat yat kārya rūpeṇa kāraṇa ātma tayā asti hi
translated: That which is non-existent in the form of an effect exists in the form of the cause.

analyzed: anavasthā anyathā hi syāt sarvatra utpatti nāśayoḥ
translated: Otherwise, there would be an infinite regress in the case of origination and destruction everywhere.

analyzed: śaktaḥ pi bhagavān viṣṇuḥ a kartum kartum anyathā
translated: Even though able, Lord Vishnu does not create, create in a different way, or destroy.

analyzed: sva bhinnam kāraṇa abhinna bhinnam viśvam karoti ajaḥ
translated: The unborn one creates the universe, which is different from Himself, and not different from the causes.

original: iti śruteravasita uktārtho 'yamaśeṣataḥ // / / //🔽anaṃśasyāpi jīvasya kiñcit sāmarthyayojanām /
analyzed: iti śruteḥ avasitaḥ ukta arthaḥ yam aśeṣatas  an aṃśasya api jīvasya kiñcid sāmarthya yojanām
translated: Thus, the meaning stated here is concluded in its entirety from the Vedic statement.

original: kāryeṣu yaḥ karotyaddhā namastasmai svayambhuve // / / //🔽yadi bhāgena kāryeṣu jīvaśaktiṃ na yojayet /
analyzed: kāryeṣu yaḥ karoti addhā namaḥ tasmai svayambhuve  yadi bhāgena kāryeṣu jīva śaktim na yojayet
translated: Even though the individual soul is partless, He who employs it in some capacity in the effects, to Him, the self-existent one, I offer salutations.🔽If Hari does not employ the individual soul's power in the effects even partially,

analyzed: hariḥ tadā hi sarvatra kṛtsna yatna ūṃśitā api vā
translated: then everywhere there would be either complete activity or partlessness.

original: aṃśino hi paṭādyā ye bhinnaireva parasparam /
analyzed: aṃśinaḥ hi paṭa ādyāḥ ye bhinnaiḥ eva parasparam
translated: For those with parts, such as cloth, etc., are different from each other.

analyzed: aṃśaiḥ aṃśinaḥ ucyante na evam eva hi cetanāḥ
translated: The parts are said to be of the possessors of parts, but the conscious beings are not so.

original: ato 'naṃśina ityeva śrutireteṣu vartate /🔽apyanekasvarūpeṣu viśeṣādeva kevalam // / / //
analyzed: atas na aṃśinaḥ iti eva śrutiḥ eteṣu vartate  api aneka svarūpeṣu viśeṣāt eva kevalam
translated: Therefore, the Śruti applies to them only as partless.🔽Even in those having many forms, it is only due to the difference.

analyzed: bahu svarūpa tā ākhyā tu teṣu asti eva hi sa aṃśa tā
translated: But the designation of having many forms is indeed the state of having parts in them.

analyzed: bahu tvena avinābhāvāt bhinna tā niyamāt bhavet
translated: Due to the invariable concomitance with multiplicity, the difference would be due to the restriction.

analyzed: yadi nā evam niyama kṛt bhagavān puruṣottamaḥ
translated: If the Supreme Lord, the best of beings, did not act in this way,

analyzed: tasya tu aśeṣa śakti tvāt yujyate sa varmā iva ca
translated: then everything would be proper for Him, due to His having all powers.

analyzed: virodhaḥ sarva vaiśiṣṭaye yaḥ dvitīye nirasyate
translated: The contradiction in all excellences, which is refuted in the second chapter,

analyzed: nārāyaṇasya tu adhyāye tad anye tatra tatragāḥ
translated: is in the chapter on Nārāyaṇa, while the others are scattered here and there.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi saṃhāra vākyānām jīva rūpa abhidhāyinām
translated: The non-contradiction of the statements about creation and dissolution, which express the forms of the individual soul,

analyzed: api anyonya avirodhaḥ tu dvitīya adhyāya gocaraḥ
translated: is also the subject matter of the second chapter.

analyzed: māna meya viśeṣeṇa punaruktiḥ na jāyate
translated: Repetition does not occur due to the difference in the object of knowledge.

analyzed: sadā pravṛttiḥ īśasya svabhāvāt eva kevalam
translated: The activity of the Lord is always only due to His own nature.

analyzed: aṅga ceṣyāḥ yathā puṃsaḥ kāścid uddeśa varjitāḥ
translated: Just as a person's limbs and desires are sometimes independent of a purpose,

analyzed: devasya eṣa svabhāvaḥ yam iti āha śrutiḥ añjasā
translated: the Śruti clearly states that this is the nature of the Lord.

analyzed: krīḍām prayojanam kṛtvā sṛṣṭiḥ śruti virodhinī
translated: The creation, which is contrary to the Vedas, is for the purpose of play.

analyzed: iti kevala līlā eva nirṇītā prabhuṇā svayam
translated: Thus, mere play alone has been determined by the Lord Himself.

analyzed: ātma prayojana arthāya spṛhām śrutiḥ avārayat
translated: The Vedas have prohibited desire for the sake of one's own purpose.

analyzed: na prayojanavat tvena iti atas āha jagadguruḥ
translated: The Lord of the universe has said that it is not for the sake of having a purpose.

analyzed: icchā mātram prabhoḥ sṛṣṭiḥ iti sṛṣṭau viniścitāḥ
translated: Those who are certain about creation say that it is merely the will of the Lord.

analyzed: iti praśaṃsayā kāma śrutibhyaḥ ca eva yuktitaḥ
translated: Thus, by praise, by the statements about desire, and by reasoning,

analyzed: mahā tātparya yukteḥ ca na icchā mātram
translated: and by the great purpose, mere will is not prohibited.

original: mokṣārthāḥ śrutayo yasmāt sa ca tasya prasādataḥ /
analyzed: mokṣa arthāḥ śrutayaḥ yasmāt sa ca tasya prasādataḥ
translated: Since the Vedas are for the sake of liberation, and that is by His grace,

analyzed: unninīṣati vākyāt ca loka dṛṣṭa anusārataḥ
translated: and from the statement about desiring, and from following the view of the world,

analyzed: icchāṃnimittakaḥ yasmāt tad abhāve kutas śrutiḥ
translated: since desire is the cause, and in its absence, how can there be a Veda?

analyzed: mahā tātparya rahitā pramāṇa tvam gamiṣyati
translated: It will not attain validity if it is devoid of great purpose.

analyzed: yāthārthyam eva māna tvam api vākyam prayojakam
translated: Truthfulness alone is the validity, or the statement is the motivator.

analyzed: māna tvam eti tatra api yat sampūrṇa prayojanam
translated: Even there, that which has a complete purpose attains validity.

analyzed: vaiṣamyam ca eva nairghṛṇyam veda aprāmāṇya kāraṇam
translated: Inequality and cruelty are the causes of the invalidity of the Vedas.

analyzed: na aṅgīkāryam atas na vaiṣamya ādi nāmakam
translated: Therefore, nothing else, such as non-uniformity, etc., should be accepted.

original: yadadhīnā guṇāścaiva doṣā api hi sarvaśaḥ /
analyzed: yad adhīnāḥ guṇāḥ ca eva doṣāḥ api hi sarvaśas
translated: He who is the controller of all qualities and even of all faults,

original: guṇāstasya kathaṃ na syuḥ syurdeṣāśca kathaṃ punaḥ // / / //
analyzed: guṇāḥ tasya katham na syuḥ syuḥ deṣāḥ ca katham punar
translated: how can he not have all good qualities? And how can he have faults again?

analyzed: sarva dharma apapatteḥ tat vākyaiḥ api hi tādṛśaiḥ
translated: Even by such statements, which are applicable to all things,

analyzed: nirdoṣa aśeṣa guṇakaḥ nirṇītaḥ bhagavān hariḥ
translated: the Blessed Lord Hari is ascertained to have all good qualities without fault.

analyzed: iti śrīmat ānandatīrtha bhagavat pāda ācārya viracite śrī brahmasūtra anuvyākhyāne dvitīya adhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the first chapter of the second section of the Anvvyakhyana on the Brahmasutras composed by the great Acharya Sriman Madhva.

analyzed: smṛti yukti śruti guṇa yuktayaḥ bahu yuktayaḥ
translated: Many arguments, such as those based on Smriti, reasoning, and the qualities of the Vedas,

analyzed: evam caturvidhāḥ nā eva viruddhayante nu ayam prati
translated: are not contradictory with regard to the doctrine of Inherence, in this way.

analyzed: iti prathama pādena nirṇīte pi abhiyogataḥ
translated: Even though it has been determined by the first section,

analyzed: darśanānām pravṛtta tvāt mandaḥ āśaṅkate punar
translated: the slow-witted one doubts again because of the prevalence of the views.

analyzed: anādi kālataḥ vṛttāḥ samayāḥ hi pravāhataḥ
translated: The conventions that have been current from beginningless time continue in a stream,

analyzed: na ca ucchedaḥ sti kasya api samayasya iti atas vibhuḥ
translated: and no convention is ever destroyed. Therefore the all-pervading Lord,

analyzed: bhrānti mūla tvam eteṣām pṛthak darśayati sphuṭam
translated: clearly shows the difference in the basis of error of these different views.

analyzed: tarkaiḥ dṛḍhatamaiḥ eva vākyaiḥ ca āgama vādinām
translated: By the most solid reasonings and by the statements of the proponents of the scriptures.

analyzed: daurlabhyāt śuddha buddhīnām bāhulyāt alpa vedinām
translated: Due to the rarity of pure intellects and the abundance of those with little knowledge,

analyzed: tāmasa tvāt ca lokasya mithyā jñāna prasaktitaḥ
translated: And due to the darkness of the world's attachment to false knowledge,

analyzed: vidveṣāt parame tattve tattva vediṣu ca aniśam
translated: And due to constant hatred for the supreme truth and those who know the truth,

analyzed: anādi vāsanā yogāt asurāṇām bahu tvataḥ
translated: Due to the connection with beginningless latent tendencies and the multitude of demons,

analyzed: durāgraha gṛhīta tvāt vartante samayāḥ sadā
translated: And due to being seized by wrong views, the conventions always persist.

analyzed: tathā api śuddha buddhīnām īśa anugraha yoginām
translated: Nevertheless, for those with pure intellects, who are endowed with the grace of the Lord,

analyzed: yuyuktayaḥ tamaḥ hanyuḥ āgama anugatāḥ sadā
translated: The proper reasonings, always following the scriptures, would destroy the darkness.

analyzed: iti vidyāpatiḥ samyak samayānām nirākṛtim
translated: Thus, Vidyapati, having properly refuted the conventions,

analyzed: cakāra nija bhaktānām buddhi śāṇa tva siddhaye  cetana acetanam tattva dvayam eva nirīśvarāḥ
translated: Composed this for the purpose of establishing the sharpness of the intellect of his devotees.

analyzed: āhuḥ tat pañca pañcatva vibhāga stham acetanam
translated: The non-theists say that the reality is only the twofold, conscious and unconscious. That unconscious reality is divided into five and five.

analyzed: cetanam bhinnam anyat layam bhavet
translated: The conscious is innumerable, separate, and would dissolve into something else.

analyzed: acetanasya kartṛ tvam svātantryeṇa nigadyate
translated: The agency of the unconscious is said to be independent.

analyzed: paraspara vibhedaḥ ca kāryāṇām ālayam bhavet
translated: And the mutual distinction of the effects would be the abode.

analyzed: bhoktṛṇām cetanasya āhuḥ kecid tām api nā apare
translated: Some say that the enjoyer, the conscious being, is also of the nature of Prakṛti, while others do not.

analyzed: svarūpa caitanya balāt sva prakāśāt ca bhogi tām
translated: Due to the power of one's own nature and consciousness, they say that enjoyment is self-luminous.

original: prakṛteśca svarūpasya vivekāgrahameva tu /🔽abhogavādino bhogamāhurbhedagrahāt tayoḥ // / / //
analyzed: prakṛteḥ ca svarūpasya viveka agraham eva tu  abhoga vādinaḥ bhogam āhuḥ bheda grahāt tayoḥ
translated: But the non-enjoyers say that it is due to the non-apprehension of the distinction between the nature of Prakṛti and the individual soul.🔽They say that enjoyment is due to the apprehension of difference between the two.

analyzed: bhoginām muktiḥ uddiṣṭā saḥ eva abhoga vādinām
translated: For the enjoyers, liberation is declared, but for the non-enjoyers, it is the same.

analyzed: īśasya asaṅgrahāt eva na yuktau tau ubhau api
translated: Due to the non-inclusion of the Lord, both of them are not proper.

analyzed: cetanā icchā anusāreṇa yadā dṛṣṭaḥ paṭa udbhavaḥ
translated: When the origin of cloth is seen in accordance with the desire of the conscious being,

original: etādṛśatvamanyasya vastutvāt kena vāryate // / / //🔽na ca kācit pramoktārthe śrutireva pramā hi naḥ /
analyzed: etādṛśa tvam anyasya vastu tvāt kena vāryate  na ca kācid pramā ukta arthe śrutiḥ eva pramā hi naḥ
translated: by what is the possibility of something else of that kind being prevented, due to its being a real entity?🔽And there is no statement of any established meaning, for us the Veda itself is the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: āpta tvam ukta mārgeṇa vaktuḥ nā evā upapadyate
translated: The authoritativeness of the path stated above is not possible for the speaker.

analyzed: a prāmāṇya svatas tvasya svīkārāt api māyi vat
translated: Even due to the acceptance of the self-validity of invalidity, like the Mīmāṃsaka,

analyzed: sva ukta akhila niṣedhī syāt na ca kiñcid
translated: there would be the denial of all that is stated by oneself, and nothing becomes established.

analyzed: idam na acetana vaśam vastu tvāt pratipanna vat
translated: This is not under the control of the insentient, because it is a real entity, like what is cognized.

analyzed: iti eva pratiṣiddhasya kena mūla anumā bhavet
translated: In this way, by whom can there be an inference of the root of what is denied?

analyzed: svatantra vṛttī racanā sā ca eva acetane kutas
translated: And that arrangement which functions independently, how can that be in the insentient?

analyzed: acetana tvam svātantryam iti
translated: The doctrine of the unconsciousness of God and His independence is refuted by our own consciousness.

analyzed: sva icchā anusāri tām eva svātantryam hi vidaḥ viduḥ
translated: The wise know independence to be the power to act according to one's own will.

analyzed: kutas icchā acetanasya sa iccham ced kim acetanam
translated: If the will of the unconscious is accepted, what is unconscious?

analyzed: icchāmi aham iti hi eva nija anubhava rodhataḥ
translated: Because of the contradiction with one's own experience, I desire.

analyzed: acetana icchā apagatāḥ yadi ca
translated: If the desire of the unconscious is removed and there is non-apprehension of difference here,

original: kathaṃ na sa ghaṭasya syānmano ma iti bhedataḥ /
analyzed: katham na sa ghaṭasya syāt manaḥ me iti bhedataḥ
translated: how would it not be of the pot, because of the difference in the mind?

analyzed: manasaḥ u pi gṛhīta tvāt ubhaya ātmaka tā yatas
translated: Because of the apprehension of the mind also, there is a dual nature.

analyzed: kāmasya tu manaḥ kāmaḥ priya apriya vibhedataḥ
translated: But the desire of the mind is desire, because of the distinction between the agreeable and disagreeable.

original: dvaividhyaṃ dṛśyate cāsya tasmād bhedāgrahaḥ kutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: dvaividhyam dṛśyate ca asya tasmāt bheda agrahaḥ kutas
translated: And duality is seen in it, therefore, how can there be non-apprehension of difference?

analyzed: racanā anupapatteḥ tat na
translated: Because of the impossibility of arrangement, it is inferred from all knowledge.

original: acetanaṃ jagatkartṛ payo 'mbvādi ca nopamā // / / //🔽etatpraśāstivacanāccetanācetanasya ca /
analyzed: acetanam jagat kartṛ payaḥ mbu ādi ca nā upamā  etad praśāsti vacanāt cetana acetanasya ca
translated: The unconscious is the maker of the world, but milk, water, etc. are not examples.🔽Because of the statement of the Lord, even in the duality of the conscious and unconscious,

analyzed: dvaividhye pitu kāma ādeḥ kutas svāmi tvam ātmanaḥ
translated: how can the self have ownership over desire, etc.?

analyzed: sākṣāt anubhava ārūḍham śakyate poditum kvacid
translated: What can be denied somewhere is what is directly experienced.

analyzed: icchā svāmi tvam eva uktam icchāvat tvam na ca aparam
translated: The state of being the Lord of desire is said to be the possession of desire, and nothing else.

analyzed: kiñcid svāmi tvam loka vat bhavet
translated: Even if something is under its control, there can be lordship like in the world.

original: sarvātmatantrakāmādeḥ kimutaiva pareśituḥ // / / //🔽na cānubhavagaṃ kāmasvāmitvaṃ vedavāgapi /
analyzed: sarva ātma tantra kāma ādeḥ kim uta eva para īśituḥ  na ca anubhava gam kāma svāmi tvam veda vāc api
translated: What to speak of the supreme Lord, whose desire is independent in all respects?

analyzed: śaktā apavaditum tasmāt sā tad anya abhidhāyinī
translated: The words of the Vedas are not able to deny the lordship of desire, which is known through experience. Therefore, the Vedas speak of something else.

analyzed: mokṣa kāmaḥ bhavet anyaḥ yadi muktāt bhaviṣyataḥ
translated: If there were another person who desires liberation, different from the one who is about to be liberated,

original: mokṣakāmasya kiṃ tena svanāśārthaṃ ca ko yatet // / / //
analyzed: mokṣa kāmasya kim tena sva nāśa artham ca kaḥ yatet
translated: what would be the use of that for one who desires liberation? And who would strive for his own destruction?

analyzed: kartṛ tvam yasya tasya eva bhoktṛ tvam upalabhyate
translated: The state of being an enjoyer is observed only in one who is an agent.

original: vibhāge ca tayormānaṃ naiva kiñcit kvacid bhavet // / / //
analyzed: vibhāge ca tayoḥ mānam nā eva kiñcid kvacid bhavet
translated: And if there were a distinction between them, there would be no evidence whatsoever anywhere.

analyzed: sarva māna virodha eka durdīkṣā dīkṣitaḥ tu ayam
translated: This one, initiated by the difficult initiation of contradicting all evidence,

analyzed: māyā vādi upamām yāyāt tad caśabdāt nirākṛtaḥ
translated: would be compared to the Mādhyamika by the word that, and would be refuted.

analyzed: sāṅkhayaḥ tu sa īśvaraḥ brūte kṣetra anugraha śaktimān
translated: The Sāṃkhya, however, says that the Lord has the power to grace the field.

analyzed: asti īśvaraḥ svayambhātaḥ kleśa karma ādi varjitaḥ
translated: The Lord exists, self-luminous, devoid of afflictions, karma, and so on.

analyzed: kṣetra śaktimatī sā eva prakṛtiḥ bīja śaktimān
translated: That very Prakṛti, endowed with the power of the field, is the seed, endowed with the power of the seed.

analyzed: jīvaḥ parjanya vat daiva śaktimān īśvaraḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: The individual soul is considered to be like Parjanya (rain), possessing divine power, and the Lord.

analyzed: pṛthivī vat pradhānam tat jīvaḥ sannidhi mātrataḥ
translated: The pradhāna is like the earth, the individual soul is merely present.

analyzed: bīja āvapana kartā iva iti atra prāha prabhuḥ svayam
translated: The Lord Himself has said that it is like one who sows seeds.

original: anyatra kāpi śaktirna svātantryeṇeśa eva hi /
analyzed: anyatra kā api śaktiḥ na svātantryeṇa īśaḥ eva hi
translated: Elsewhere, there is no other power. The Lord alone is independent.

analyzed: śaktīḥ tāḥ prerayati añjas tad adhīnāḥ ca sarvadā
translated: He directs those powers, and they are always under His control.

analyzed: sattā pradhāna puruṣa śaktīnām ca pratītayaḥ
translated: The perceptions and activities of existence, pradhāna, puruṣa, and the individual soul,

original: pravṛttayaśca tāḥ sarvā nityaṃ nityātmanā yataḥ // / / //
analyzed: pravṛttayaḥ ca tāḥ sarvāḥ nityam nitya ātmanā yatas
translated: all of them are always eternal, because of the eternal Self.

analyzed: yathā nitya tayā nityam nitya śaktayā svayā īśvaraḥ
translated: Just as the eternal Lord always controls with His eternal power,

original: niyāmayati nityaṃ ca na ṛte tvaditi śruteḥ // / / //
analyzed: niyāmayati nityam ca na ṛte tvat iti śruteḥ
translated: because of the Vedic statement not without You,

analyzed: svabhāva jīva karmāṇi dravyam kālaḥ śrutiḥ kriyāḥ
translated: Nature, individual souls, actions, substance, time, scripture, and rituals,

analyzed: yad prasādāt ime santi na santi yad upekṣayā
translated: are existent by His grace, and non-existent by His neglect.

original: iti śruterna sattādyā api nārāyaṇaṃ vinā /
analyzed: iti śruteḥ na sattā ādyāḥ api nārāyaṇam vinā
translated: Thus, existence and so on are not without Nārāyaṇa.

original: tatpatañjalivindhyādimataṃ na puruṣārthadam // / / //🔽cārvākairucyate mānamakṣajaṃ nāparaṃ kvacit /
analyzed: tat patañjali vindhya ādi matam na puruṣa artha dam 🔽cārvākaiḥ ucyate mānam akṣa jam na aparam kvacid
translated: The philosophy of Patañjali, Vindhya, and others does not lead to human goals.🔽The Cārvākas say that perception alone is valid, not any other means of knowledge.

original: deha ātmā pumarthaśca kāmārthābhyāṃ vinā na hi // / / //
analyzed: dehaḥ ātmā pumarthaḥ ca kāma arthābhyām vinā na hi
translated: The self of the body and the purpose of the soul are not without desire and wealth.

analyzed: yat evam darśanena asya kaḥ rthaḥ pratyakṣa gocaraḥ
translated: What is the purpose of this view, which is the object of perception?

original: labdhastenaiva hi naraiḥ śāstrāt kiṃ mohanaṃ vinā // / / //
analyzed: labdhaḥ tena eva hi naraiḥ śāstrāt kim mohanam vinā
translated: By that alone, men have attained. What is the use of the scriptures without delusion?

analyzed: sva para artha vihīna tvāt sva matena eva niṣphalam
translated: It is fruitless by its own opinion, due to the absence of one's own and others' purposes.

analyzed: kim iti unmatta vat śāstram vṛthā pralapati svayam
translated: Why does the scripture babble like a madman in vain by itself?

analyzed: dehāt anyaḥ nubhavate ātmā bhāti śarīriṇām
translated: The self of embodied beings shines as different from the body,

original: mama deha iti vyaktaṃ mamārtha itivat sadā // / / //
analyzed: mama dehaḥ iti vyaktam mama arthaḥ iti vat sadā
translated: as this is my body is always like this is my purpose.

analyzed: pratyakṣasya eva māna tvam iti kena avasīyate
translated: By whom is it ascertained that perception alone is valid?

original: yadi tatsādhakaṃ vedaprāmāṇye na kathaṃ bhavet // / / //
analyzed: yadi tat sādhakam veda prāmāṇye na katham bhavet
translated: If that is the proof of the validity of the Vedas, how could it not be?

analyzed: na ca anya amāna tā kvāpi pramāṇena avasīyate
translated: And the invalidity of others is not ascertained anywhere by a means of knowledge.

analyzed: sva matena artha rahitaḥ upekṣyaḥ pakṣaḥ īdṛśaḥ
translated: Such a position, devoid of meaning by one's own opinion, should be ignored.

analyzed: sannidhānāt cetanasya vartate yadi acetanam
translated: If the insentient exists due to the proximity of the sentient,

analyzed: tathā api abuddhi pūrva tvāt ukta doṣaḥ samaḥ bhavet
translated: even then, the stated fault would be the same due to the absence of intelligence.

analyzed: aṅgi tvam puruṣasya eva sarvaiḥ api anubhūyate
translated: The status of being an agent is experienced by all as belonging to the person alone.

analyzed: tad aṅga tva uktitaḥ ca eva syāt sarvasya apalāpakaḥ
translated: And also because of the statement of its being a part, there would be denial of everything.

analyzed: kimu sarveśvarasya asya hi apalāṣāt yatas khilam
translated: What to speak of the denial of this Lord of all, from whom everything...

analyzed: aṅgi tvam yadi tasya eva svātantryam ced na ca akhilam
translated: If it is the status of being the controller of that alone, and not of all,

analyzed: tad preraṇe pi aśakta tvāt svatantraḥ nyaḥ hi apekṣitaḥ
translated: then even in the instigation of that, due to the incapacity, another independent one is required...

analyzed: na ca svātantryam asya eva pratyakṣa ādi virodhataḥ
translated: And not the independence of that alone, due to the contradiction with perception etc.,

original: hitākṛtyādidoṣācca bhadraṃ nānīśvaraṃ matam // / / //🔽saṃsāriṇo 'nyaṃ sarveśaṃ sarvaśaktimanaupamam /🔽cetanācetanasyāsya sattvādestadadhīnatām /
analyzed: hita ākṛti ādi doṣāt ca bhadram na anīśvaram matam  saṃsāriṇaḥ sarva īśam sarva śaktim anaupamam  cetana acetanasya asya sattva ādeḥ tad adhīna tām
translated: and due to the fault of not doing what is beneficial etc., the good is not considered to be God...🔽Those who do not accept the dependence of this conscious and unconscious existence on Him, the all-pervading Lord, the all-powerful one, the incomparable one,

original: nāṅgīkurvanti ye teṣāṃ sarveṣāṃ ca samā ime // / / //
analyzed: na aṅgīkurvanti ye teṣām sarveṣām ca samāḥ ime
translated: on Him who is different from the transmigrating beings, on all of them these are the same...

analyzed: tasmāt śruti pramāṇena yuktibhiḥ ca paraḥ hariḥ
translated: Therefore, by the authority of the Vedas and by reasonings, the highest Hari,

original: aṅgīkāyartamo nityaḥ sarvairapi suniścitam // / / //🔽nityajñānaprayatnecchaṃ saṅkhayadyairapi pañcabhiḥ /
analyzed: aṅgīkā yartamaḥ nityaḥ sarvaiḥ api su niścitam  nitya jñāna prayatna iccham saṅkha yad yaiḥ api pañcabhiḥ
translated: who is to be accepted as eternal, should be ascertained by all...

analyzed: yuktam īśam vadanti anye tad icchā dṛṣṭa coditāḥ
translated: Others, impelled by the unseen force of His will, declare the Lord to be endowed with eternal knowledge, effort, and will, and with the five qualities of sound etc.

analyzed: paramāṇavaḥ catur vargāḥ saṃyujyante dviśas khilāḥ
translated: And the atoms of the four classes all combine in pairs...

analyzed: paramāṇu dvayena eva dvayaṇukam nāma jāyate
translated: By the combination of two atoms, a dyad is produced.

analyzed: dvayaṇuka trayeṇa tṛyaṇukam taiḥ caturbhiḥ tad ātmakam
translated: By the combination of three dyads, a triad is produced, and by the combination of four of those, a tetrad is produced.

analyzed: tatas tu aniyamena eva khaṇḍa avayavinām bhavaḥ
translated: Then, without any restriction, the production of parts and wholes takes place.

analyzed: tatas ca aniyamena eva sarva avayavi sambhavaḥ
translated: And then, without any restriction, the production of all parts and wholes takes place.

analyzed: kāraṇam samavāyi ākhyam paramāṇu ādi tatra hi
translated: The cause is called inherence, beginning with atoms, for in that case,

original: īśecchādṛṣṭakālāstu nimittaṃ kāraṇaṃ matam // / / //🔽sāmānyāntyaviśeṣau ca samavāyaśca tattrayam /
analyzed: īśa icchā dṛṣṭa kālāḥ tu nimittam kāraṇam matam  sāmānya antya viśeṣau ca samavāyaḥ ca tat trayam
translated: the will of the Lord, unseen [potency], and time are considered the instrumental cause.

original: nityaṃ kriyā anityāstu guṇadravye dvirūpake // / / //🔽kārye guṇakriyāṇāṃ tu samavāyyanyakāraṇam /
analyzed: nityam kriyāḥ anityāḥ tu guṇa dravye dvi rūpake  kārye guṇa kriyāṇām tu samavāyi anya kāraṇam
translated: Universals, the final specific individualities, and inherence - these three are eternal. Actions are non-eternal, and qualities and substances have two forms.🔽But for qualities and actions in an effect, inherence and another cause are the cause.

analyzed: kāraṇa sthāḥ guṇa ādyāḥ tu saṃyogaḥ dravya kāraṇam
translated: The qualities etc. residing in the cause, conjunction is the cause of substance.

analyzed: evam sthite siddhānte viśeṣaḥ tatra kalpitaḥ
translated: Even though this is the established conclusion, a distinction is imagined there.

analyzed: dvayaṇuke paramāṇau ca hrasva tvam parimaṇḍalam
translated: In a dyad and an atom, there is shortness and circularity.

original: na kāraṇaṃ kāryaguṇe vairūpyaṃ tatra kāraṇam /
analyzed: na kāraṇam kārya guṇe vairūpyam tatra kāraṇam
translated: The cause is not the cause of the quality of an effect. Dissimilarity is the cause there.

analyzed: iti āhuḥ tān atha uvāca vidyādhīśaḥ svayam prabhuḥ
translated: Thus they say. Then the Lord himself, the master of knowledge, said to them.

analyzed: mahat tvam ca eva dīrgha tvam tṛ yaṇuka ādyeṣu kalpitam
translated: And largeness and length are imagined to exist in triads and so on.

analyzed: tasmāt ca sadṛśam kāryam tat kāryeṣu upajāyate
translated: Therefore, an effect similar to that is produced in its effects.

analyzed: yathā tathā eva hrasva tvāt hi
translated: Just as, in the same way, from shortness and sphericity,

analyzed: jāyeta sadṛśam kārye parimāṇam sama tvataḥ
translated: An effect of similar size would be produced due to equality.

original: na cenmahattvataścaiva dīghartvādapi no bhavet /🔽sadṛśasya hi kāryasya naiva yogaḥ kathañcana // / / //
analyzed: na ced mahattvataḥ ca eva dīghartvāt api no bhavet  sadṛśasya hi kāryasya na eva yogaḥ kathañcana
translated: If not, then from largeness also, and from length also,🔽There can be no connection at all with an effect of similar size.

analyzed: apratyakṣa tvam evam syāt yatas kāryeṣu aṇu tvataḥ
translated: Thus, atomicity in effects would be imperceptible.

analyzed: iti ced na mahat tvam ca paramāṇau aṇau api
translated: If so, then largeness would also be in the atom.

analyzed: katham tṛyaṇuka pūrveṣu na aṇu tvam api kathyate  pratyakṣa tva tad anya tve puruṣa apekṣayā akhile
translated: How is atomicity not also mentioned in those preceding the triad?🔽Perceptibility and imperceptibility depend entirely on the person,

original: aṇutvaṃ ca mahattvaṃ ca yato vastuvyapekṣayā // / / //
analyzed: aṇu tvam ca mahat tvam ca yatas vastu vyapekṣayā
translated: Because largeness and smallness depend on the object.

original: tāratamyasthitā yasmāt padārthāḥ sarva eva ca /🔽yathā mahattvaviśrāntistathāṇutvasya ceṣyate // / / //
analyzed: tāratamya sthitāḥ yasmāt padārthāḥ sarve eva ca  yathā mahattva viśrāntiḥ tathā aṇu tvasya ca iṣyate
translated: Because all things exist in a state of gradation,🔽Just as largeness is accepted, so also atomicity is desired.

analyzed: parimāṇa tvataḥ ced na mahat tvasya api viśramaḥ
translated: If not, then there would be no resting place even for largeness,

original: dṛśyate 'nanta ityeva tathānantyamaṇāvapi // / / //🔽na mahattatvaguṇata etāvāniti hīśvaraḥ /
analyzed: dṛśyate nantaḥ iti eva tathā ānantya maṇau api  na mahat tatva guṇataḥ etāvān iti hi īśvaraḥ
translated: It is seen as infinite, and so also in the atom of infinity.🔽The Lord is not limited to this much by the quality of the great principle.

analyzed: paricchinnaḥ tathā aṇoḥ ca na etāvat bhāga tā kvacid
translated: And in the atom also, there is no such partial existence anywhere.

analyzed: viśrāntaḥ yadi ananta aṃśaḥ kaścid asti iti gamyate
translated: If it is understood that some infinite part rests,

analyzed: na avasāyayitum śakyaḥ virodhāt eva kevalam
translated: it can only be concluded due to contradiction alone.

analyzed: kevalam sākṣi mānena kālaḥ deśaḥ na antavān
translated: Only by the cognition of the witness, time and space are also infinite.

analyzed: aparyavasitiḥ ca aṇoḥ dṛśyate sakṣiṇā dvayoḥ
translated: The non-termination of the atom is seen by the witness in both cases.

original: yadi no sākṣigamyaṃ tanmahattvaṃ kena gamyate /
analyzed: yadi no sākṣi gamyam tat mahat tvam kena gamyate
translated: If that greatness is not known by the witness, by what is it known?

analyzed: viśrāntiḥ tāratamyena dṛśyate hi anumānataḥ
translated: The resting point is seen by inference through gradation.

analyzed: yadi āgamāt anantam tat mahattvam avagamyate
translated: If that infinity is understood by scripture as greatness,

analyzed: anantam eva ca aṇu tvam kutas nā evā avasīyate
translated: why is not even the infinity of minuteness ascertained?

analyzed: mahat tva aṇu tvayoḥ nā eva viśrāntiḥ upalabhyate
translated: The resting point is not perceived in greatness and minuteness.

analyzed: anyat eva hi ananta tvam mahat tva aṇu tvayoḥ samam
translated: For infinity is different, equal to greatness and minuteness.

analyzed: bahu tva alpa tvayoḥ yadvat sāṅkhayāyām upalabhyate
translated: Just as multiplicity and fewness are perceived in the Sāṅkhya system,

analyzed: ānantyam eka bhāgānām tāvat tvam hi eva gaṇyate
translated: The infinity of parts is counted as such only.

analyzed: aṇīyān ca mahīyān ca bhagavān āgama uditaḥ
translated: The Lord is said in the scriptures to be smaller and greater.

analyzed: ānantya vācakaḥ śabdaḥ dvidhā ānantye māna tām
translated: The word infinity has validity in both kinds of infinity.

original: yāti naiva guṇālpatvaṃ kālātpatvaṃ ca mānagam /
analyzed: yāti nā eva guṇa alpatvam ca māna gam
translated: There is no decrease in quality or increase in time due to scripture.

analyzed: sarva kāla gatasya alpa kāle syāt avasthitiḥ
translated: Even in a small time, there would be existence of what exists in all times.

original: mahāguṇasya cālpo 'pi guṇaḥ syāditi ced bhavet /
analyzed: mahā guṇasya ca alpaḥ pi guṇaḥ syāt iti ced bhavet
translated: If it is argued that even a small quality would be of a great quality, it would be so.

original: tāvattvameva naiva syād deśe 'pyetanna no matam // / / //
analyzed: tāvat tvam eva nā eva syāt deśe pi etat na naḥ matam
translated: That very finiteness would not be, and we do not accept it even in space.

analyzed: mahataḥ lpatvam api hi vyoma vat prāha veda vid
translated: The knower of the Veda says that even a great thing can be small, like space.

analyzed: yadi alpa deśa saṃsthānam na sarvatra api no bhavet
translated: If it does not exist everywhere, even in a small place,

analyzed: sthitasya hi alpa deśeṣu sarvaga tvam bhavet dhruvam
translated: then it would certainly be all-pervading, existing in small places.

analyzed: ekatra api anavasthasya kutas evā akhila stha tā
translated: How can there be existence everywhere for what does not even exist in one place?

original: śūnyatvameva tasya syād yasyaikatrāpi na sthitiḥ /
analyzed: śūnya tvam eva tasya syāt yasya ekatra api na sthitiḥ
translated: For one who does not exist even in one place, it would be just emptiness.

analyzed: atas nā aṇu tva viśrāntiḥ na mahat tvasya ca kvacid
translated: Therefore, finiteness does not rest anywhere, nor does greatness.

analyzed: ubhaya ānantya yuj tasmāt yadi mukhya mahat bhavet
translated: Therefore, if greatness were primary, it would be endowed with both kinds of infinity.

original: tacca brahma paraṃ sākṣāt sarvānantyayutaṃ sadā // / / //
analyzed: tat ca brahma param sākṣāt sarva ānantya yutam sadā
translated: And that Brahman is the supreme Reality itself, always accompanied by all infinity.

original: yadi sākṣī svayambhāto na mānaṃ kena gamyate /
analyzed: yadi sākṣī svayambhātaḥ na mānam kena gamyate
translated: If the witness is self-evident, by what means is it known?

original: akṣajādeśca mānatvamanavasthāthavā bhavet // / / //🔽ataḥ sarvapadārthānāṃ bhāgāḥ santyeva sarvadā /
analyzed: akṣaja ādeḥ ca māna tvam anavasthā athavā bhavet  atas sarva padārthānām bhāgāḥ santi eva sarvadā
translated: And the validity of perception and other means of knowledge would lead to an infinite regress.🔽Therefore, all things always have parts.

analyzed: sarva dikṣu api sambandhāt avibhāgaḥ para aṇu tā
translated: And because of the connection in all directions, there is no division, but atomic size.

analyzed: tad saṃyogāt aniyatāt padārthānām janiḥ bhavet
translated: The birth of things would be from the irregular conjunction of those.

analyzed: dvayoḥ eva tu saṃyogaḥ iti kena avasīyate
translated: But how is it ascertained that there is conjunction of only two?

analyzed: kāraṇasya guṇāḥ tena bhaveyuḥ kārya gāḥ api
translated: Therefore, the qualities of the cause may also be present in the effect.

analyzed: tāratamyena sarve mahāntaḥ ca aṇavaḥ yatas
translated: Because all of them are great and atomic to a certain extent.

original: na ca tatproktasṛṣṭau tu mānaṃ kevalakalpanā /
analyzed: na ca tad prokta sṛṣṭau tu mānam kevala kalpanā
translated: And in that creation described by him, there is no valid means of knowledge, but only imagination.

analyzed: katham sākṣi mitasya asya śaknuyāt vāraṇe kvacid
translated: How could it ever succeed in preventing this, which is known by the witness?

original: yadi sākṣimitaṃ naitannānumā tatra vartate /🔽pakṣīkartumaśakyatvāt kuta evānumā bhavet // / / //
analyzed: yadi sākṣi mitam na etat na anumā tatra vartate  pakṣīkartum aśakya tvāt kutas evā anumā bhavet
translated: If this is not known by the witness, inference does not operate there.🔽Because it is impossible to formulate a subject, how could there be inference at all?

analyzed: yatra nā asti pada nyāsaḥ kaḥ tam viṣayam āpnuyāt
translated: Where there is no application of words, who could attain that object?

analyzed: deśa antara ādi śabdaḥ ca śaśa śṛṅga ādi śabda vat
translated: And the words 'other place' etc. are like the words 'hare's horn' etc.

original: sadṛśaṃ ca sajātīyaṃ nāsmatpakṣe kim eva hi /
analyzed: sadṛśam ca sajātīyam na asmad pakṣe kim eva hi
translated: And what is similar is of the same class, not in our view at all.

analyzed: yena eva ca prakāreṇa ati asiddham anumīyate
translated: And by the very same method by which the absolutely non-existent is inferred,

analyzed: tena eva śaśṛṅga ādeḥ śakyam astitva kalpanam
translated: by that very same method, the existence of the hare's horn etc. can be imagined.

analyzed: pratyakṣam āgamaḥ vā api bhavet yatra niyāmakaḥ
translated: Where there is either perception or scripture as the determiner,

analyzed: sā eva vyāptiḥ bhavet mānam na anyā sandigdha mūlataḥ
translated: that alone would be the valid cognition of pervasion, not another, because of the doubtful basis.

analyzed: saha darśana mātreṇa na vyāptiḥ avasīyate
translated: Pervasion is not ascertained merely by the observation of co-existence.

analyzed: yadā eva avyatirekasya hi akṣa jam vā āgamaḥ bhavet
translated: When there is either a sense-perception or scripture of non-deviation,

analyzed: tad nirdhārita yuktiḥ vā vyāptiḥ sā eva aparā na hi
translated: then that alone is the ascertained pervasion by reasoning, not another.

analyzed: anyathā
translated: Otherwise, even the existence of the seventh taste would be established by inference.

analyzed: aniṣṭāni ca sarvāṇi hi anumā kāma cāriṇī
translated: And all undesirable things would also be established by inference, as inference acts as it pleases.

original: kāryakāraṇayoścaiva guṇādeḥ pañcakasya ca /🔽bhinnasyaiva tu sambandhaḥ samavāyo 'nya īryate // / / //
analyzed: kārya kāraṇayoḥ ca eva guṇa ādeḥ pañcakasya ca  bhinnasya eva tu sambandhaḥ samavāyaḥ nyaḥ īryate
translated: And between effect and cause, and also between the five such as quality etc.,🔽a different relation called inherence is indeed postulated.

analyzed: bhinna tva sāmyataḥ tasya tābhyām yogaḥ bhavet dhruvam
translated: Due to the similarity of difference, it would certainly be connected with those two.

original: sa svanirvāhakaścet syād dravyameva tathā na kim // / / //
analyzed: sa sva nirvāhakaḥ ced syāt dravyam eva tathā na kim
translated: If it were to be the cause of its own existence, why not the substance itself be so?

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ tad gata tva ādiḥ yadi abhinne vasīyate
translated: If the difference, such as inherence, etc., is determined in the non-different,

original: guṇakriyādirūpasya niṣedhaḥ kena hetunā // / / //🔽dravyameva tato 'nantaviśeṣātmatayā sadā /
analyzed: guṇa kriyā ādi rūpasya niṣedhaḥ kena hetunā  dravyam eva tatas nanta viśeṣa ātma tayā sadā
translated: by what reason is the negation of the form of quality, action, etc. made?🔽Therefore, the substance itself is always the cause of various usages due to having infinite differences.

analyzed: nānā vyavahṛteḥ hetuḥ ananta tvam viśeṣataḥ
translated: The infinity is due to the difference.

analyzed: viśeṣaḥ ca viśeṣī saḥ svena eva samavāya vat
translated: And that difference is the differentia itself, like inherence itself.

analyzed: kalpanā guru tā doṣāt padārtha antara tā na hi
translated: Due to the fault of excessive imagination, it is not a different category.

original: kalpayitvā ṣaṭ padārthān sābhāvānapi kevalam /🔽ekasmin sa viśeṣaścet kiṃ pūrvaṃ tasya vismṛtiḥ // / / //
analyzed: kalpayitvā ṣaṭ padārthān sa abhāvān api kevalam  ekasmin sa viśeṣaḥ ced kim pūrvam tasya vismṛtiḥ
translated: Having imagined the six categories, including non-existence alone,🔽if that difference is in one, why was it forgotten before?

analyzed: yena pratyakṣa siddhena vyavahāraḥ khilaḥ bhavet
translated: By which [difference] all usage would be [possible], which is established by perception,

original: bhāvābhāvavibhāgena yaṃ vinā na kathañcana // / / //🔽abhedena pratītiśca kāryakāraṇapūrvake /
analyzed: bhāva abhāva vibhāgena yam vinā na kathañcana  abhedena pratītiḥ ca kārya kāraṇa pūrvake
translated: without which [difference] it is never [possible] due to the distinction between existence and non-existence.🔽And the cognition is non-different in this category of existent and non-existent, which is preceded by cause and effect,

analyzed: abhāva ante padārthe smin sa viśeṣā avasīyate
translated: the particular is determined.

analyzed: sāmānya ādi padārtheṣu tad niṣṭha tva ādayaḥ khilāḥ
translated: In the categories such as universal, etc., all such as the relation to that [universal] are

original: kathaṃ dharmā nivāryante vastvaikye 'pi hi vādibhiḥ // / / //
analyzed: katham dharmāḥ nivāryante vastu aikye hi vādibhiḥ
translated: How are things obstructed even when there is unity of substance by the disputants?
The effect's belonging to that and that is due to the pervasiveness etc. of the quality and so on.

original: kathaṃ viśeṣo naivāsti sa ca dharmo 'paro yadi // / / //
analyzed: katham viśeṣaḥ na evā asti sa ca paraḥ yadi
translated: How is there no difference at all if that is another property?

analyzed: ṣaṣ padārtha atirekaḥ syāt padārtha aniyame hi
translated: There would be an excess over the six categories, for even when the categories are restricted,

analyzed: dharmasya dharma santānāt anavasthā karaḥ bhavet
translated: the property would cause an infinite regress due to the continuity of properties.

analyzed: sāmānyasya api sāmānyam guṇasya api guṇaḥ hi atas
translated: The universal also has a universal, and the quality also has a quality, therefore,

original: nāṅgīkṛtaḥ sa ca yadi nānavasthā kvacid bhavet // / / //
analyzed: na aṅgīkṛtaḥ sa ca yadi nā anavasthā kvacid bhavet
translated: if that is not accepted, there would be no infinite regress anywhere.

analyzed: asmad pakṣe guṇa ādyāḥ ca tadvantaḥ hi viśeṣataḥ
translated: In our view, the qualities and so on also belong to that, because of the particular.

analyzed: ananya tvāt nā anavasthā bhedaḥ nāśe bhavet tathā
translated: There is no infinite regress due to non-difference, and the difference would be in the destruction.

analyzed: viśeṣam eva saṃśritya viśeṣaḥ balavān yatas
translated: Because the particular is indeed powerful, relying on the particular itself.

analyzed: dṛṣṭi pramāṇataḥ ca eva virodhaḥ darśane katham
translated: And how is there contradiction in the view due to the evidence of perception?

analyzed: virodhaḥ hi avirodhaḥ ca yatas darśana māna gau
translated: For contradiction and non-contradiction are based on perception and inference.

analyzed: tatas dṛṣṭe virodhaḥ tu sadbhiḥ āpādyate katham
translated: Therefore, how is contradiction in the seen imposed by the good?

analyzed: abhinnaḥ bhagavān svena tad anyena vibhedavān
translated: The Lord is non-different by Himself, and different by that which is different from Him.

analyzed: nityāḥ dharmāḥ tadīyāḥ tu sarve smāt nā eva bhedinaḥ
translated: But their properties are eternal and all of them are not different from it.

analyzed: sāmastya ucchedinaḥ nyatra dharmāḥ ubhaya rūpakāḥ
translated: In other cases, the properties are of both kinds, destroying the whole.

original: bhāve ta eva cocchedāt tadanye ca samastaśaḥ // / / //
analyzed: bhāve te eva ca ucchedāt tad anye ca samastaśas
translated: And in existence, those very [properties] are destroyed, and all the others are completely destroyed.

analyzed: aṃśa aṃśinoḥ abhedena tu aṃśa saṃyogaḥ eva hi
translated: Because of the non-difference between the part and the whole, the conjunction is only of the parts.

analyzed: aṃśinaḥ na anavasthātaḥ yadi api aṃśeṣu aviśramaḥ
translated: Even though there is no resting of the whole in the parts, there is no infinite regress due to the part.

original: ekasmin jāta evānyaḥ saṃyogo jāyate yadi /
analyzed: ekasmin jāte eva anyaḥ saṃyogaḥ jāyate yadi
translated: If another conjunction is produced only when one is produced in one [part],

original: anavasthā tadaiva syāt saṃyogaikye bhavet kva sā // / / //
analyzed: anavasthā tadā eva syāt saṃyoga aikye bhavet kva sā
translated: then there would be an infinite regress right then. Where would it be if the conjunctions were one?

analyzed: aṃśe saṃyoga dṛṣṭeḥ ca dṛṣṭe kā sā anavasthitiḥ
translated: And because the conjunction is seen in the part, what is the infinite regress in what is seen?

original: yadyaṃśago na saṃyogaḥ kāryeṣu prathimā katham // / / //
analyzed: yadi aṃśa gaḥ na saṃyogaḥ kāryeṣu prathimā katham
translated: If the conjunction does not belong to the parts, how is there extension in the effects?

analyzed: paramāṇoḥ aṇoḥ nā asti mahat tā iti adbhutam vacaḥ
translated: The statement that there is no extension in an atom or an atom is wonderful.

analyzed: aṇūnām prathima apekṣām vinā eva saḥ
translated: Without the dependence on extension of the atoms, it [extension] is in the triad of atoms alone.

analyzed: paramāṇoḥ mahat tvam ca vinā iti etat vacaḥ katham
translated: How is it that there is no extension in an atom?

analyzed: aṃśinaḥ ṃśaiḥ abhedaḥ yam aṃśena tu bhidā abhidā
translated: This is the non-difference of the whole from the parts, but the difference and non-difference from the part.

analyzed: sarva pratyakṣa viṣayaḥ katham eva hi apohyate
translated: How indeed is this, which is the object of all perception, to be denied?

analyzed: saṃyogaḥ ca vibhāgaḥ ca bhedaḥ ca eva pṛthak pṛthak
translated: Conjunction and disjunction, and difference, are seen separately,

analyzed: anyonya pratiyogena hi ubhayoḥ api dṛśyate
translated: of both, by mutual opposition.

original: bhinnā iti tu bhedānāṃ samudāyo hi dṛśyate /
analyzed: bhinnāḥ iti tu bhedānām samudāyaḥ hi dṛśyate
translated: But the collection of differences is seen as 'different'.

analyzed: yathā eva ca padārthānām anayoḥ bhedaḥ iti api
translated: And just as the difference between these two things is also seen,

analyzed: itas muṣya amutas pi asya bhedaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ dvidharmikaḥ
translated: the difference of this from that, and of that from this, is seen as having two properties.

analyzed: tatra eka vacanam yat tat viprāṇām bhojanam yathā
translated: There, that which is singular is like the Brahmins' meal.

analyzed: nara tva ādikam api evam tad tad dharma tayā iyate
translated: In the same way, humanity and so on are also considered to have their own properties.

original: na sarvadharma eko 'sti samudāyastu bhinnagaḥ // / / //🔽etādṛśaṃ ca sādṛśyaṃ padārtheṣu pṛthak pṛthak /
analyzed: na sarva dharmaḥ ekaḥ sti samudāyaḥ tu bhinna gaḥ  etādṛśam ca sādṛśyam padārtheṣu pṛthak pṛthak
translated: There is no single universal property, but the collection is different.🔽And such similarity is in the individual things separately,

analyzed: ekasmin sa vinaṣṭe yatas nyatra eva dṛśyate
translated: when it is seen elsewhere even when one is destroyed.

analyzed: kutas bhasma tvam āptasya nara tvam punar iṣyate
translated: How can humanity be accepted again for one who has attained the state of ashes?

original: ekatve nāsti mānaṃ ca śrutirapyāha sādaram // / / //🔽bhinnāśca bhinnadharmāśca padārthā akhilā api /
analyzed: ekatve nā asti mānam ca śrutiḥ api āha sādaram  bhinnāḥ ca bhinna dharmāḥ ca padārthāḥ akhilāḥ api
translated: And there is no valid cognition of oneness, the Veda also declares emphatically.🔽All the things are different and have different properties,

analyzed: svaiḥ svaiḥ dharmaiḥ abhinnāḥ ca sva rūpaiḥ api sarvaśas
translated: and are also inseparable by their own properties and by their own forms in every way.

analyzed: anivṛtta vināśāḥ tu dharmāḥ ubhaya rūpakāḥ
translated: But things whose destruction is not obstructed are of both kinds.

analyzed: na bhagavān sva guṇaiḥ vinā
translated: Therefore, the Blessed One is not identical with anything, being devoid of His own qualities.

analyzed: iti vyutpattiḥ api hi sādṛśyena eva gamyate
translated: Thus, even the understanding is comprehended only through similarity.

analyzed: sarveṣu yugapad śabdaḥ sadṛśeṣu pravartate
translated: The word 'all' is used simultaneously for similar things.

original: tathāpi prāptitastvekavacanācca viśeṣataḥ /🔽abhīṣyāvagatiśca syācchaktiḥ sādṛśyagā yataḥ // / / //
analyzed: tathā api prāptitaḥ tu ekavacanāt ca viśeṣataḥ  abhīṣya avagatiḥ ca syāt śaktiḥ sādṛśya gā yatas
translated: Nevertheless, there is the cognition of fear from the attainment and the singular number,🔽because the power is based on similarity.

original: tādṛśo 'yaṃ ca tacchabda iti jñāpayati sphuṭam /
analyzed: tādṛśaḥ yam ca tad śabdaḥ iti jñāpayati sphuṭam
translated: Thus, the word 'that' clearly indicates that this is similar to that.

analyzed: jātitaḥ ced katham tāsu tatra ced anavasthitiḥ
translated: If it is by genus, how is it in those? If it is there, there is infinite regress.

analyzed: tathā eva vyakti vijñānam vyakti tva abhāva dūṣitam
translated: The cognition of the individual in the same way is tainted by the absence of individuality.

analyzed: yadi tat ca asti tasya api viśeṣeṣu anavasthitiḥ
translated: If that also exists, then there is infinite regress even in those.

analyzed: katham svarūpa tvam api jñāyate nugatam yadi  eka vyutpatti paryantam anavasthā ādi dūṣitam
translated: How is the nature also known if it is not universal?🔽The infinite regress, etc. are tainted by the end of the understanding of one.

analyzed: kalpanā gauravāt tena yuktā na anuga kalpanā
translated: Therefore, the imagination of the universal is proper due to the heaviness of imagination.

analyzed: aupādhika viśiṣṭa ādyam api tat vastu kim tatas
translated: Is that thing also qualified by the adventitious distinction, or is it different from that?

original: anyat tadeva cedagnimattvaṃ kiṃ tatra bhaṇyate // / / //🔽agnisaṃyogamātraṃ ced bhavet tat siddhasādhanam /
analyzed: anyat tat eva ced agnimat tvam kim tatra bhaṇyate  agni saṃyoga mātram ced bhavet tat siddha sādhanam
translated: If it is the same as that, then what is to be said about the presence of fire there?🔽If it is merely the contact with fire, then that is a futile argument.

analyzed: bhūdharasya agni saṃyogaḥ yadi ṣaṣṭhayarthe eva kaḥ
translated: If the contact of the mountain with fire is only the meaning of the genitive case, then what is the use of postulating inherence?

original: samavāyo yadi hy asya caikatvāt siddhasādhanam /
analyzed: samavāyaḥ yadi hi asya ca eka tvāt siddha sādhanam
translated: If inherence is the relation between the two, then it is a futile argument, because it is one.

original: yadyasyaupādhiko bhedaḥ kuta ekatvamiṣyate // / / //🔽nānirvācyaṃ hi teneṣyamata aupādhikānyayoḥ /
analyzed: yadi asya aupādhikaḥ bhedaḥ kutas eka tvam iṣyate  na anirvācyam hi tena iṣyam atas aupādhika anyayoḥ
translated: If the difference is due to an accidental property, then how can oneness be accepted?

analyzed: satya tvāt kaḥ viśeṣaḥ syāt māyā vādī anyathā bhavet
translated: Because of the truth of the two, what would be the difference? It would be otherwise for the Mādhyamika.

analyzed: upādhi janyam tat gamyam iti vā aupādhikam bhavet
translated: It would be accidental because it is produced by an accidental property and is known by that.

analyzed: ubhayatra api anantāḥ syuḥ samavāyāḥ itas tatas
translated: In both cases, there would be infinite inherences from here and there.

original: bhinnatvaṃ caiva teṣvasti ko viśeṣa upādhige // / / //🔽avidyamāna evānyaḥ samavāyo 'dhigamyate /
analyzed: bhinna tvam ca eva teṣu asti kaḥ viśeṣaḥ upādhi ge  a vidyamānaḥ eva anyaḥ samavāyaḥ dhigamyate
translated: And there is difference among them. What is the special feature of the inherence of an accidental property?🔽Inherence is known to be non-existent.

analyzed: upādhinā tad gamakam anumānam na mā bhavet
translated: Let there not be inference produced by an accidental property, which is the means of knowing it.

analyzed: evam eva asataḥ satta samavāyaḥ janiḥ matā
translated: In the same way, the inherence of non-existence in existence is accepted as production.

analyzed: tatra api hi ukta doṣāṇām na eva kiñcid nivārakam
translated: For there also, nothing prevents the stated faults.

analyzed: asmad pakṣe viśeṣasya sarvatra aṅgīkṛta tvataḥ
translated: In our view, the distinction is accepted everywhere,

original: nāsti doṣaḥ kvacid bhāvo hyabhāvaśca sa eva hi // / / //
analyzed: na asti doṣaḥ kvacid bhāvaḥ hi abhāvaḥ ca saḥ eva hi
translated: so there is no fault anywhere. Existence is indeed non-existence.

original: abhāvasya ca dharmāḥ syurbhāvāsteṣāṃ ca te 'khilāḥ /🔽pratyakṣamānataḥ sarvametanno vāraṇakṣamam /
analyzed: abhāvasya ca dharmāḥ syuḥ bhāvāḥ teṣām ca te khilāḥ  pratyakṣa mānataḥ sarvam etat naḥ vāraṇa kṣamam
translated: And the properties of non-existence would be existences, and all of those are🔽of perception and inference, all of this is not capable of refuting us.

analyzed: sarve bhāvāḥ abhāvāḥ ca padārthāḥ tena sarvadā
translated: Therefore, all existences and non-existences are objects at all times.

original: tathāpi prathamaṃ buddheryo niṣedhasya gocaraḥ /🔽so 'bhāvo vidhibuddhestu gocaraḥ prathamaṃ paraḥ // / / //
analyzed: tathā api prathamam buddheḥ yaḥ niṣedhasya gocaraḥ  saḥ bhāvaḥ vidhi buddheḥ tu gocaraḥ prathamam paraḥ
translated: Nevertheless, the first object of the intellect is the sphere of negation,🔽that is non-existence. But the sphere of the subsequent intellect is existence.

analyzed: tasmāt pradhvasta bheda ādi sat iti eva avagamyate
translated: Therefore, it is understood that difference, etc. are destroyed and it exists.

analyzed: asti abhāvaḥ sti ca dhvaṃsaḥ deha abhāvaḥ ca bhasma tā
translated: Existence is non-existence, destruction is the non-existence of the body, and ashes.

analyzed: ityādi yujyate sarvam pratyakṣa ādi pramāṇataḥ
translated: Thus, all this is proper according to perception and other means of knowledge.

original: anyonyābhāvabhedau ca pṛthaktavaṃ ca pṛthak pṛthak // / / //
analyzed: anyonya abhāva bhedau ca pṛthaktavam ca pṛthak pṛthak
translated: And mutual non-existence, difference, and separateness are separate from each other.

analyzed: yat kalpayanti tat ca eva kalpanā gauravāt gatam
translated: And that which they imagine is also gone due to the heaviness of imagination.

original: paryāyatvena te śabdā jñāyante sarva eva hi // / / //
analyzed: paryāya tvena te śabdāḥ jñāyante sarve eva hi
translated: All those words are known to be synonyms.

original: bhedasya tu svarūpatve ye vadanti ca śūnyatām /
analyzed: bhedasya tu sva rūpa tve ye vadanti ca śūnyatām
translated: But those who say that emptiness is the nature of difference,

analyzed: adbhuta tāḥ te yatas nyasya pratiyogi tvam iṣyate
translated: For, it is from that which is wondrous that the relation of counter-correlate is accepted for another.

original: pratiyogino hi bhedo 'yaṃ natu svasmāt kathañcana /
analyzed: pratiyoginaḥ hi bhedaḥ yam na tu svasmāt kathañcana
translated: For this difference is of the counter-correlate, not at all from itself in any way.

original: vibhāgenālpataiva syāt kuta eva ca śūnyatā // / / //
analyzed: vibhāgena alpatā eva syāt kutas eva ca śūnyatā
translated: By division, there would be only a small amount, and how much less emptiness?

original: na śūnyānāṃ hi saṃyogād bhāvo vastuna iṣyate /
analyzed: na śūnyānām hi saṃyogāt bhāvaḥ vastunaḥ iṣyate
translated: For the existence of a thing is not accepted from the conjunction of the non-empty.

analyzed: vidāraṇa arthaḥ dhātuḥ ca vibhāga guṇa vācakaḥ
translated: And the verbal root 'vi-bhid' (to divide) has the quality of division as its denotation.

original: avidāraṇe 'pi hyāsyasya bhinnāvoṣṭhau tu tasya ca /
analyzed: a vidāraṇe hi āsyasya bhinnau oṣṭhau tu tasya ca
translated: For even in the non-division of the mouth, the lips are divided, but not that.

analyzed: atas unmatta vākya tvāt māyā vādaḥ bhyupekṣitaḥ
translated: Therefore, because of being like the speech of a madman, the doctrine of illusion is accepted.

analyzed: na ca amanda sat ānanda syandi ananta guṇa arṇavaḥ
translated: And the ocean of infinite qualities, which is the stream of infinite bliss,

analyzed: īśvaraḥ ṣṭaguṇa tvena prameyaḥ pramita tvataḥ
translated: the Lord is to be known as having eight qualities, because of being not known.

analyzed: mayi ananta guṇe nante guṇataḥ nanta vigrahe
translated: In me, who have infinite qualities, who am infinite, who have an infinite body by virtue of qualities,
the ocean of infinite knowledge of the greatness and power of qualities,

analyzed: nārāyaṇaḥ śeṣa cetanebhyaḥ param padam
translated: Narayana is superior to all conscious beings, the highest position.

analyzed: ityādi veda tad vākyaiḥ anantaiḥ ca avasīyate
translated: Thus, it is ascertained by the Vedas and their statements, and by infinite others.

analyzed: ananta guṇa tā viṣṇoḥ katham eva hi apodyate
translated: How is the infinity of qualities of Vishnu to be refuted?

analyzed: yadi ananta viśeṣāḥ ca tad jñāna ādeḥ nivāritāḥ
translated: If they are infinite and distinct, and are excluded by the knowledge of that (Brahman),

analyzed: katham tad tad viṣaya tā sārvajñya artham vidhīyate
translated: how is the state of being the object of each (of those infinite and distinct things) enjoined for the sake of omniscience?

analyzed: aupādhika viśeṣaḥ tu pūrvam eva nirākṛtaḥ
translated: But the accidental distinction has already been refuted earlier.

analyzed: sva prakāśa tvam api tu yaiḥ jñānasya nivāritam
translated: But those who have excluded the self-luminous nature of knowledge,

analyzed: katham sarvajña tā tasya sva jñāna adhigamam vinā
translated: how can he be omniscient without the realization of his own knowledge?

analyzed: jñānam viśva adhigam tu ekam tad jñāna viṣayam param
translated: The one knowledge that comprehends the universe is supreme in being the object of that knowledge.

analyzed: iti jñāna dvayena eva sarva vid parameśvaraḥ
translated: Thus, by these two knowledges alone, the omniscient Supreme Lord is

analyzed: iti ced eṣaḥ eva arthaḥ tad jñāna avasitaḥ yadi
translated: If this very meaning is determined by that knowledge,

analyzed: sva prakāśa tvam eva syāt jñānam hi etat viśeṣaṇam
translated: then there would be self-luminousness itself, for this is a qualification of knowledge.

analyzed: jñāna antareṇa ced atra bhavet evā anavasthitiḥ
translated: If it is by another knowledge, then there would certainly be infinite regress here.

original: svaprakāśatvametasmād durnivāryaṃ samāpatet // / / //🔽sukhavān duḥkhavāṃśca syāditi vyāptiśca no bhavet /
analyzed: sva prakāśa tvam etasmāt durnivāryam samāpatet  sukhavān duḥkhavān ca syāt iti vyāptiḥ ca no bhavet
translated: Therefore, self-luminousness would inevitably follow from this.🔽And the pervasion that he would be both happy and unhappy would not be for us.

analyzed: nirduḥkha tvam mahānandaḥ śrutyā evā īśasya bhaṇyate
translated: The absence of suffering and great bliss of the Lord is stated by the scriptures themselves.

analyzed: śanāyā pipāse ca śoka ādīn ca ativartate
translated: He who transcends hunger, thirst, sorrow and so on,

original: ānandaṃ brahmaṇo vidvān vipāpmetyādikā ca sā // / / //
analyzed: ānandam brahmaṇaḥ vidvān vipāpmā iti ādikā ca sā
translated: And that beginning with knowing bliss in Brahman, free from sin, and so on.

analyzed: īśvarasya tathā iṣṭatvam duḥkhi tva upādhiḥ iti api
translated: And the fact that it is desired by God is also a limiting adjunct of His being a sufferer.

analyzed: ukte kim uttaram brūyāt śruti anādara tatparaḥ
translated: When this is stated, what answer can one give who is solely intent on disregarding the scriptures?

analyzed: na ca ātma duḥkhitā icchā syāt atas etat nivāryate
translated: And there would be no desire for the suffering of the self, therefore this is prevented.

analyzed: saha darśana mātreṇa śrutīnām apalāpakaḥ
translated: One who denies the scriptures merely on seeing them together...

original: yajñāder api pāpasya hetutvaṃ hiṃsayā yuteḥ /🔽nānumāti kathaṃ tatra yadyupādhirniṣiddhatā // / / //
analyzed: yajña ādeḥ api pāpasya hetu tvam hiṃsayā yuteḥ  nā anumāti katham tatra yadi upādhiḥ niṣiddha tā
translated: The fact that sacrifice etc. are also causes of sin due to being associated with violence,🔽how does one not infer there if the prohibition is a limiting adjunct?

analyzed: aduḥkhi tvena ca anuktiḥ katham nā upādhi tām vrajet
translated: And how does the statement not being made due to non-suffering not become a limiting adjunct?

original: aduḥkhamitarat sarvaṃ jīvā eva tu duḥkhinaḥ /
analyzed: aduḥkham itarat sarvam jīvāḥ eva tu duḥkhinaḥ
translated: All else is non-suffering, but only the individual souls are suffering.

analyzed: teṣām duḥkha prahāṇāya śrutiḥ eṣā pravartate
translated: This scripture proceeds for the cessation of their suffering.

original: iti śrutirhi paramā śrutyuktir yadi kāraṇam /
analyzed: iti śrutiḥ hi paramā śruti uktiḥ yadi kāraṇam
translated: For if the statement of the scriptures is the reason,

analyzed: kim kāryam anumānena gaḷa stana samena hi
translated: what is the purpose of inference, which is like a blind man's palm?

analyzed: anumānena yadi arthaḥ śruti dṛṣṭaḥ vyapodyate

analyzed: adṛṣṭa kālayoḥ ca eva bhāvāt kāryam sadā bhavet

analyzed: rūpa sparśa ādi hetubhyaḥ paramāṇoḥ anitya tā

analyzed: anumeyā śrutīnām ca viruddha tvāt na tat matam

analyzed: upādeyam atas ca ayam aviruddhaḥ samanvayaḥ

analyzed: vaibhāṣikāḥ ca sautrāntāḥ svarasa kṣaṇikam jagat

analyzed: aṇūnām samudāyam ca kāla karma nimittataḥ

translated: The continuity of these [five aggregates] always exists in the form of the five aggregates.🔽Existence in the form of formations, consciousness, perception, and suffering,

analyzed: atas ṛtha indriya saṃyogi rūpa kāraṇa tā ātmanaḥ

analyzed: saṃyogi rūpa rāhityāt nā eva tad jñāna tā api hi

analyzed: viśa ṣaṣ kārya janakam yadi kāraṇam iṣyate

analyzed: kutas samāna rūpa tvam kāryāṇām api sarvaśas

analyzed: atas niyatyā yat kiñcid yasya kasya api kāraṇam

analyzed: adṛṣṭasya api tasya eva viśeṣa āpādakam kutas

analyzed: yasya kasya api yat kiñcid viśeṣam upapādayet

analyzed: iti nitya vināśi tve kena mānena gamyate

analyzed: idam na jāyate muṣmāt iti atra api na kāraṇam

analyzed: vināśa utpattayaḥ ca eva na dṛśyante sadātanāḥ

analyzed: tena api aṅgīkṛtaḥ samyak sa naḥ satya tvam eva hi

analyzed: vijñānāt vyabhicāraḥ syāt kadācid syāt iti pramā
translated: There may be some deviation of this from cognition at some time, so it is valid knowledge.

original: naiva dṛṣṭā pramā sā ca na bhavet svavirodhataḥ // / / //
analyzed: nā eva dṛṣṭā pramā sā ca na bhavet sva virodhataḥ

analyzed: bhedaḥ viśeṣya dharmi ādi grahaṇa apekṣayā yadi

analyzed: anyonya āśraya tā hetoḥ durgāhyaḥ iti yat na tat

original: svarūpaṃ vastuno bhedo yanna tasya grahe grahaḥ /
analyzed: svarūpam vastunaḥ bhedaḥ yat na tasya grahe grahaḥ
translated: The difference of an object is its own form, and when it is not apprehended, it is not apprehended.

analyzed: anyathā asya amunā bhedaḥ iti vaktum na yujyate

analyzed: agṛhītaḥ yadā bhedaḥ tadā svasmāt iti grahaḥ

original: syāt pratītivirodhācca na hi kaścit tathā vadet // / / //🔽dharmitvapratiyogitvatadbhedā yugapad yadi /
analyzed: syāt pratīti virodhāt ca na hi kaścid tathā vadet

analyzed: viśeṣaṇam viśeṣyam ca tad bhāvaḥ ca eva gṛhyate
translated: then the qualifier, the qualified, and their relation are apprehended.

original: ko virodhaḥ svarūpeṇa gṛhīto bheda eva tu /

analyzed: asya amuṣmāt iti punar viśeṣeṇa eva gṛhyate

original: kiñca bhedaḥ kathaṃ grāhya iti yaḥ paripṛcchati /
analyzed: kiñca bhedaḥ katham grāhyaḥ iti yaḥ paripṛcchati
translated: Moreover, one who asks how difference is to be grasped,

translated: by grasping the difference of the substratum etc., he has stated the mutual dependence.🔽If difference is not grasped, how can there be mutual dependence?

analyzed: anya tvam yadi siddham syāt katham anyonya saṃśrayaḥ
translated: If difference were established, how can there be mutual dependence?

analyzed: etādṛśasya vaktārau ubhau jāti uttara akarau
translated: Those who speak like this, both of them are givers of sophistical answers.

analyzed: māyī mādhyamikaḥ ca eva tad upekṣyau bubhūṣubhiḥ
translated: The magician and the Mādhyamika should be ignored by those who desire liberation.

analyzed: yat śūnya vādinaḥ śūnyam tat eva brahma māyinaḥ
translated: That which is empty for the proponents of emptiness, that alone is Brahman for the magicians.

original: na hi lakṣaṇabhedo 'sti nirviśeṣatvatastayoḥ // / / //🔽anṛtādivirodhitvamubhayośca svalakṣaṇam /🔽svavākyābhāvasaṃvādānna kṛtyaṃ prativādinaḥ // / / //
analyzed: na hi lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ sti nirviśeṣa tvataḥ tayoḥ  anṛta ādi virodhi tvam ubhayoḥ ca sva lakṣaṇam  sva vākya abhāva saṃvādāt na kṛtyam prativādinaḥ
translated: There is no difference in definition, because both are without distinctions.🔽The specific characteristic of both is being opposed to falsehood etc.

original: tatpakṣa iti vaidharmyānna svapnādivadityajaḥ /🔽aprayatnānnirācakre ceti dṛṣṭiviruddhatām /
analyzed: tad pakṣaḥ iti vaidharmyāt na svapna ādi vat iti ajaḥ  aprayatnāt nirācakre ca iti dṛṣṭi viruddha tām
translated: Due to the contradiction with one's own statement, the opponent has no duty.🔽The unborn one has rejected the argument 'like a dream etc.' on the ground that it is not accepted by both parties.

analyzed: niṣpramāṇa tvam api asya sūcayāmāsa viśvakṛt
translated: The creator of the universe has also indicated its lack of evidence by showing that it is contradicted by perception.

analyzed: jñānam eva ekam akhila jñeya ākāram prabhāsate

original: tatra santatibhedaśca svabhedo bheda eva ca /
analyzed: tatra santati bhedaḥ ca sva bhedaḥ bhedaḥ eva ca
translated: There, continuity, self-difference, and difference

analyzed: bhāsate nubhavasya eva viruddha tvāt apeśalam

translated: And due to the momentariness of knowledge and the stable nature of the knowable object,🔽as stated earlier, all these positions are in contradiction with the scriptures

analyzed: anubhūti viruddha tvāt api pakṣāḥ ime śivāḥ

analyzed: āha kṣapaṇakaḥ viśvam sat asat dvayam advayam

analyzed: sapta bhaṅgi sadātanam

analyzed: na etat padārthe ekasmin yuktam dṛṣṭi virodhataḥ
translated: This is not proper in one thing, due to contradiction with perception.

analyzed: bhāva abhāva tayā viśvam yena rūpeṇa mīyate
translated: In whatever form the universe is measured as existent or non-existent,

analyzed: tad rūpam eva tat iti niyamaḥ kena vāryate  tad tad doṣa nivṛtti artham svīkṛtā tad tad ātmanā

analyzed: atihāya pramāṇa āptam niyamam sat asat tayā

analyzed: sva vyāhata tvam ityādyāḥ doṣāḥ sarve bhavanti hi

analyzed: duṣyam nānā śarīreṣu praveśāt anyathābhavāt

analyzed: dūṣyate mahatī devī hrīṅkarī sarva kāraṇam

analyzed: anubhūti virodhena katham eka tvam ucyate

analyzed: sarvajñaḥ bhagavān viṣṇuḥ sarva śaktiḥ iti śrutaḥ

analyzed: anubhūtāt hi bhedena śrutiḥ eṣā vadati amum

analyzed: dharmi grāhi virodhaḥ tu tasmāt mānasya dūṣaṇam

analyzed: na upajīvyaḥ hi abhedaḥ kvacid bheda śruteḥ balāt

analyzed: sarva jñāna maya evā īśaḥ yadi upeyaḥ kathañcana
translated: If the Lord is somehow to be reached by all knowledge,
