translated: For the experience that there is the enjoyment of happiness of Indra and others, indeed, becomes angry.

analyzed: tasmāt amukta sukha gam tāratamyam pṛthak pṛthak
translated: Therefore, having stated the gradation of happiness of the unliberated separately,

original: uktvā yaśceti muktānāṃ tāratamyaṃ sukhe śrutiḥ /
analyzed: uktvā yaḥ ca iti muktānām tāratamyam sukhe śrutiḥ
translated: the scripture speaks of the gradation of happiness of the liberated, using the word 'ca' (and).

analyzed: āha iti peśalam tat ca caśabdāt eva gamyate
translated: And that is appropriate, for it is understood from the word 'ca' itself.

analyzed: rāddhaḥ saṃsiddhaḥ iti eva muktaḥ eva avagamyate
translated: It is said that only the liberated one is understood to be 'rāddha' (accomplished).

original: sādhunā viṣṇunā yukto muktaḥ sādhuyuvā mataḥ // / / //
analyzed: sādhunā viṣṇunā yuktaḥ muktaḥ sādhu yuvā mataḥ
translated: The liberated one who is united with the virtuous Viṣṇu is considered to be 'sādhuyuva' (having a virtuous youth).

original: yauvanaṃ nityametasya muktasyeti yuvā sa ca /
analyzed: yauvanam nityam etasya muktasya iti yuvā sa ca
translated: And he is 'yuva' (youthful) because this liberation has eternal youth.

original: phalamadhyayanasyāptaṃ tenādhyāyaka īritaḥ // / / //🔽nirhrāsānandasamprāptyā cāśiṣṭa iti gīyate /
analyzed: phalam adhyayanasya āptam tena adhyāyakaḥ īritaḥ  nirhrāsa ānanda samprāptyā ca āśiṣṭaḥ iti gīyate
translated: He is called 'adhāyaka' (teacher) because he has attained the fruit of studying.🔽He is said to be 'āśiṣṭha' (most blessed) due to attaining the diminished bliss.

analyzed: sthitasya ananyathā prāpteḥ dṛḍhiṣṭhaḥ iti coditaḥ
translated: He is declared to be 'dṛḍhiṣṭha' (most firm) because of the attainment of stability without change.

analyzed: baliṣṭhaḥ ca svabhāvena muktaḥ bhavati kevalam
translated: And the liberated one becomes simply 'balistha' (most powerful) by nature.

original: tasyeyaṃ pṛthivītyādi pūrvabhāvavyapekṣayā // / / //🔽sa eka iti saṃsāragatamuktavā sukhaṃ punaḥ /
analyzed: tasya iyam pṛthivī ityādi pūrva bhāva vyapekṣayā  saḥ ekaḥ iti saṃsāra gatam uktavā sukham punar
translated: 'This earth is his' etc. is with reference to the previous state.🔽Having spoken of the happiness of the liberated one in the state of worldly existence,

analyzed: śrotriyasya iti vadati muktāt śataguṇa ātma tām
translated: he again says 'śrotriya' (learned in the Vedas) to indicate the hundredfold superiority of the liberated one's happiness.

analyzed: saṃsāragāt ca saṃsāra gatasya eva śata adhikam
translated: And for one in the world, it is a hundred times more for one who is in the world.

analyzed: muktāt muktasya yuktam syāt śruti uktam abhivīkṣitaḥ
translated: It is proper for one who is liberated to have more than one who is not liberated, when seen in the light of the scriptures.

analyzed: yuktam ca sādhana ādhikyāt sādhya ādhikyam surā ādiṣu
translated: And it is proper that there should be superiority in the objects of attainment due to the superiority of the means of attainment among the gods and others.

original: nādhikyaṃ yadi sādhye syāt prayatnaḥ sādhane kutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: na ādhikyam yadi sādhye syāt prayatnaḥ sādhane kutas
translated: If there were no superiority in the objects of attainment, then why make an effort in the means of attainment?

analyzed: yatnaḥ ca dṛśyate teṣām mahān eva mahātmanām
translated: And effort is seen to be very great indeed in those great souls,

analyzed: yatra sādhana bāhulyam sādhya bāhulyam atra ca
translated: where there is abundance of means of attainment and abundance of objects of attainment.

original: dṛṣṭaṃ niyamato no cenna yatnaṃ kuryarañjasā // / / //
analyzed: dṛṣṭam niyamataḥ no ced na yatnam kuryaḥ añjasā
translated: If it were not seen to be so, one would not make an effort at all.

analyzed: kṛcchreṇa sādhanāt eva na mukta vat udīryate
translated: It is said that liberation is not obtained merely by difficult means.

analyzed: daśa kalpam tapaḥ cīrṇam rudreṇa lavaṇārṇave
translated: Rudra practiced austerities for ten kalpas in the salt ocean,

analyzed: tyaktavā sukhāni sarvāṇi kliṣṭena lavaṇāmbhasā
translated: renouncing all pleasures, tormented by the salty water.

analyzed: śakreṇa varṣa koṭiḥ ca dhūmaḥ ti duḥkhataḥ
translated: Indra, with great sorrow, drank smoke for a million years.

analyzed: varṣa ayutam ca sūryeṇa tapaḥ vāc śirasā kṛtam
translated: The sun, with its head down, performed austerities for ten thousand years.

analyzed: su duḥkhena sukham tyaktavā dharmeṇa ākāśa śāyinā
translated: Dharma, lying in the sky, renounced pleasure with great difficulty.

analyzed: pītāḥ mayīcayaḥ varṣa sāhasram ati sādaram
translated: He respectfully drank a mass of dust for a thousand years.

analyzed: atikṛcchreṇa kurvanti yatnam brahma vidaḥ hi
translated: Even those who know Brahman make efforts with great difficulty.

analyzed: iti etat akhilam mokṣa viśeṣa abhāvataḥ katham
translated: How is all this possible due to the absence of distinction in liberation?

analyzed: daivī sampad vimokṣāya nibandhāya āsurī matā
translated: The divine wealth is considered for liberation, and the demoniacal for bondage.

analyzed: iti mokṣa viśeṣaḥ ca svayam bhagavatā uditaḥ
translated: Thus, the distinction in liberation has also been stated by the Lord Himself.

analyzed: tam eva yūyam bhajata ātma vṛttibhiḥ manaḥ vacaḥ kāya guṇaiḥ sva karmabhiḥ
translated: You should worship Him with your own actions, with the qualities of mind, speech, and body,

analyzed: amāyinaḥ kāmadughā aṅghri paṅkajam yathā adhikārāḥ avasita artha siddhaye
translated: without deceit, for the attainment of the desired goal, according to one's capacity, the lotus feet which are like a wish-fulfilling cow.

analyzed: akṣaṇvantaḥ karṇavantaḥ sakhāyaḥ manaḥ javeṣu asamāḥ babhūvuḥ
translated: The friends who have no elbows, who have ears, have become unequal in the speed of the mind.

original: ādaghnāsa upakakṣāsa u tve hradā iva snātvā u tve dadṛśre // / / //
analyzed: ādaghnāsaḥ upakakṣāsaḥ u tve hradāḥ iva snātvā u tve dadṛśre
translated: They have seen you, with their arms reaching the knees, with their armpits, as if having bathed in a lake.

analyzed: ityādīni ca vākyāni tāratamyam vimukti gam
translated: And such statements clearly speak of the gradation in liberation.

original: vyaktaṃ vadanti tat kena sāmyaṃ mukteṣu gamyate // / / //
analyzed: vyaktam vadanti tat kena sāmyam mukteṣu gamyate
translated: By whom is equality among the liberated ones understood?

original: duḥkhādyabhāvasāmyaṃ ca sāmyavākyārtha īyate /🔽bhaktayādiguṇasadbhāve hyatulyatvaṃ ca bhārate /
analyzed: duḥkha ādi abhāva sāmyam ca sāmya vākya arthaḥ īyate  bhaktayā ādi guṇa sadbhāve hi atulya tvam ca bhārate
translated: And the meaning of the statement of equality is understood as the absence of suffering and so on.🔽For the presence of devotion and other qualities, and the inequality, are stated in the Mahabharata.

analyzed: uktam sādhana vaiśeṣyam api sarvatra kathyate
translated: The excellence of the means is also stated everywhere.

analyzed: durjñeyam ghora rūpasya trailokya dhvaṃsinaḥ prabhoḥ
translated: It is difficult to know the nature of the terrible form of the Lord who destroys the three worlds.

analyzed: daivataiḥ munibhiḥ siddhaiḥ mahā yogibhiḥ eva ca
translated: By the gods, sages, Siddhas, great yogis,

analyzed: nitya yuktaiḥ mahābhāgaiḥ vimukta kleśa sādhvasaiḥ
translated: Who are always devoted, greatly fortunate, free from the fear of afflictions,

analyzed: mahā utsāhaiḥ mahā dhairyaiḥ sattvasthaiḥ vyavasāyibhiḥ
translated: Of great enthusiasm, great patience, established in goodness, determined,

analyzed: atīta anāgata jñāna prabhava apyaya vedibhiḥ
translated: Who know the past and future, the origin and dissolution,

analyzed: śauca svādhyāya santoṣa tapaḥ satya dayā anvitaiḥ
translated: Endowed with purity, self-study, contentment, austerity, truthfulness, and compassion,

analyzed: kimu martyaiḥ bhaya bhrānti dhvaṃsa moha rujā anvitaiḥ
translated: What to speak of mortals who are afflicted with fear, delusion, pride, disease,

analyzed: alpa āyuḥ vīrya dhī sattva vyavasāya śruti vrataiḥ
translated: Short-lived, of little vigor, intellect, courage, determination, and Vedic vows.

analyzed: kaḥ tam madāmadam devam mad anyaḥ jñātum arhati
translated: Who else but Him can know that God who is intoxicated and intoxicating?

original: brahmaiva kiñcijjānāti na tadanyo hi kaścana // / / //🔽muktānāmapi siddhānāṃ nārāyaṇaparāyaṇaḥ /
analyzed: brahma eva kiñcid jānāti na tad anyaḥ hi kaścana  muktānām api siddhānām nārāyaṇa parāyaṇaḥ
translated: Brahma alone knows a little, not anyone else.🔽Even among the liberated Siddhas, O greatly wise one, one who is devoted to Narayana,

analyzed: su durlabhaḥ praśānta ātmā koṭiṣu api mahāmate
translated: With a tranquil mind, is extremely rare, even in millions.

original: iyaṃ visṛṣṭiryata ā babhūva yadi vā dadhe yadi vā na /
analyzed: iyam visṛṣṭiḥ yatas ā babhūva yadi vā dadhe yadi vā na
translated: From whom this creation has come into being, whether He exists or not,

original: yo asyādhyakṣaḥ parame vyoman tso aṅga veda yadi vā na veda // / / //
analyzed: yaḥ asya adhyakṣaḥ parame vyoman tsaḥ aṅga veda yadi vā na veda
translated: He who is the overseer of this (universe) in the highest heaven, he knows this limb, or if he does not know.

original: yaḥ svātmamāyāvibhavaṃ svayaṃ gato nāhaṃ nabhasvāṃstamathāpare kutaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ sva ātma māyā vibhavam svayam gataḥ na aham nabhasvān tam atha apare kutas
translated: He who has himself gone to the manifestation of his own illusory power, I, the wind, and others, not at all.

original: brahmāpi yaṃ vetti naiveha samyaganye kuto devamunīndramartyāḥ // / / //
analyzed: brahmā api yam vetti nā evā iha samyak anye kutas deva muni indra martyāḥ
translated: Brahma himself does not know him properly in this world, what to speak of others, gods, sages, lords, mortals.

original: namaste 'mitatattvāya dharmādīnāṃ ca sūtaye /🔽nirguṇāya ca satkāṣṭhāṃ nāhaṃ vedāpare kutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: namaḥ te mita tattvāya dharma ādīnām ca sūtaye  nirguṇāya ca satkāṣṭhām na aham veda apare kutas
translated: Salutations to you, of infinite truth, and to the creator of dharma and others.

original: nāhaṃ parāyur ṛṣayo na marīcimukhyā jānanti yadviracitaṃ khalu sattvasaṅgāḥ /🔽yanmāyayā muṣitacetasa īśadaityamartyādayaḥ kimuta śaśvadabhadravṛttāḥ // / / //
analyzed: na aham para āyuḥ ṛṣayaḥ na marīci mukhyāḥ jānanti yat viracitam khalu sattva saṅgāḥ  yad māyayā muṣita cetasaḥ īśa daitya martya ādayaḥ kim uta śaśvat abhadra vṛttāḥ
translated: To the one without qualities, I do not know even a fraction of your true nature, what to speak of others.

original: ahaṃ mahendro nirṛtiḥ pracetāḥ somo 'gnirīśaḥ pavano 'rko viriñcaḥ /
analyzed: aham mahā indraḥ nirṛtiḥ pracetāḥ somaḥ gniḥ īśaḥ pavanaḥ rkaḥ viriñcaḥ
translated: I, the great Indra, Nirriti, Prachetas, Soma, Agni, Ishana, the wind, the sun, Virincha,

original: ādityaviśve vasavo 'tha sādhyā marudgaṇā rudragaṇāḥ sasiddhāḥ // / / //
analyzed: āditya viśve vasavaḥ tha sādhyāḥ marut gaṇāḥ rudra gaṇāḥ sa siddhāḥ
translated: The Adityas, the Vishvadevas, the Vasus, the Sadhyas, the Marut and Rudra hosts, with the Siddhas,

analyzed: anye ca ye viśvasṛjaḥ mara īśāḥ bhṛgu ādayo spṛṣṭa rajaḥ tamaskāḥ
translated: And others, the creators of the universe, the lords of the immortals, Bhrigu and others, untouched by rajas and tamas qualities.

original: yasyehitaṃ na viduḥ spṛṣṭṛmāyāḥ sattvapradhānā api kiṃ tato 'nye // / / //
analyzed: yasya īhitam na viduḥ spṛṣṭṛ māyāḥ sattva pradhānāḥ api kim tatas nye
translated: Whose will those who are touched by Maya, even the foremost of beings, do not know, what to speak of others?

analyzed: savarsī ādau smṛtaḥ brahmā tasmāt devāt anantaraḥ
translated: Brahma is remembered as the first among the gods, after him.

analyzed: jānāti deva pravaram bhūyas ca atas dhikam nṛpa
translated: He knows the foremost of gods and more than that, O king.

analyzed: na tvām atiśayiṣyanti muktau api kathañcana
translated: But they will never surpass you even in liberation.

analyzed: mad bhakti yogāt jñānāt ca sarvān atiśayiṣyasi
translated: By devotion to me and by knowledge, you will surpass all.

analyzed: yathā bhakti viśeṣaḥ tra dṛśyate puruṣottame
translated: Just as there is seen a special devotion here in the Supreme Being,

analyzed: tathā mukti viśeṣaḥ pi jñāninām liṅga bhedane
translated: so also there is a special liberation for the knowers in the breaking of the Linga.

analyzed: sāyujyam samanuprāptāḥ api deva ādayaḥ khilāḥ
translated: Even all the gods who have attained union,

analyzed: tāratamyāt hi tiṣṭhanti tāratamyam hi sādhane
translated: remain due to the gradation, for the means have gradation.

analyzed: manuṣyāṇām sahasreṣu kaścid yatati siddhaye
translated: Out of thousands of men, one perhaps strives for perfection.

analyzed: yatatām api siddhānām kaścid mām vetti tattvataḥ
translated: Even among those who have attained perfection, one perhaps knows Me truly.

analyzed: yaḥ imam paramam guhyam mad bhakteṣu abhidhāsyati
translated: He who will proclaim this supreme secret to My devotees,

analyzed: bhaktim mayi parām kṛtvā mām eva eṣyati asaṃśayaḥ
translated: having fixed his highest devotion in Me, will certainly come to Me alone.

analyzed: na ca tasmāt manuṣyeṣu kaścid me priya kṛttamaḥ
translated: And there is none dearer to me than he among men.

original: bhavitā na ca me tasmādanyaḥ priyataro bhuvi // / / //
analyzed: bhavitā na ca me tasmāt anyaḥ priyataraḥ bhuvi
translated: And there is none dearer to me than he on earth.

original: adhyeṣyate ca ya imaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃvādamāvayoḥ /
analyzed: adhyeṣyate ca yaḥ imam dharmyam saṃvādam āvayoḥ
translated: And he who will study this discourse on duty between us two,

analyzed: jñāna yajñena tena aham iṣṭaḥ syām iti me matiḥ
translated: I think, will be regarded by him as worshipped with the sacrifice of knowledge.

analyzed: śraddhāvān anasūyuḥ ca śṛṇuyāt api yaḥ naraḥ
translated: And he who, full of faith and free from malice, will listen to this,

original: so 'pi muktaḥ śubhān lokān prāpnuyāt puṇyakarmaṇām // / / //
analyzed: saḥ pi muktaḥ śubhān lokān prāpnuyāt puṇya karmaṇām
translated: He also, being freed, will attain the worlds of the virtuous.

analyzed: dhyānena ātmani paśyanti kecid ātmānam ātmanā
translated: Some see the Self by the Self in the Self by meditation,

analyzed: anye sāṅkhayena yogena karma yogena ca apare
translated: Others by the Yoga of Sankhya, and others by the Yoga of action.

analyzed: anye tu evam a jānantaḥ śrutvā anyebhyaḥ upāsate
translated: But others, not knowing thus, worship by hearing from others,

original: te 'pi cātitarantyeva mṛtyuṃ śrutiparāyaṇāḥ // / / //🔽susūkṣmairapyaśeṣaiśca viśeṣaiḥ saha paśyati /
analyzed: te ca atitaranti eva mṛtyum śruti parāyaṇāḥ  su sūkṣmaiḥ api aśeṣaiḥ ca viśeṣaiḥ saha paśyati
translated: They also, intent on the Vedas, surely cross death.

analyzed: sva ātmānam bhagavān viṣṇuḥ sarva rūpaḥ sarvadā
translated: The Lord Vishnu, though of all forms, always sees the Self by the Self with even the subtlest distinctions.

original: savartra cānyadapyevaṃ tenādṛṣṭaṃ na hi kvacit /
analyzed: ca anyat api evam tena adṛṣṭam na hi kvacid
translated: And so he sees nothing unseen by him anywhere.

analyzed: sarvatra sarva daiva īśam paśyati eva ramā api tu
translated: But Lakshmi always sees the Lord everywhere.

analyzed: na tu sarvaiḥ viśeṣaiḥ tam paśyanti api anyatas dhikam
translated: But even those who see Him do not see Him with all His attributes, but only as superior to others.

analyzed: sva ātmānam anyat ca aśeṣam paśyati eva hi sarvadā
translated: But He always sees His own Self and everything else.

analyzed: brahmā tu sarvagam paśyet guṇān api atas dhikam
translated: But Brahma sees Him as all-pervading and also with more attributes than that.

analyzed: na tu sarveṣu kāleṣu tathā paśyati amukti gaḥ
translated: But one who is not liberated does not always see Him in this way.

original: muktastu sarvadā paśyet sarvagatvena cāpi tu /
analyzed: muktaḥ tu sarvadā paśyet sarvaga tvena ca api tu
translated: But one who is liberated always sees Him as all-pervading.

original: na ramāvad viśeṣāṇāṃ darśanaṃ śaknuyāt kvacit // / / //
analyzed: na ramāvat viśeṣāṇām darśanam śaknuyāt kvacid
translated: But he cannot see the distinctions anywhere like Rama.

analyzed: sva ātmānam anyat ca sadā viśeṣaiḥ akhilaiḥ api
translated: But he always sees his own Self and everything else with all the distinctions.

analyzed: paśyanti añjas tathā vāṇī viśoṣān tāvataḥ na tu
translated: The wind and speech see in the same way, but not the distinctions to that extent.

original: traiguṇyāt parataḥ paśyed vyāptaṃ śataguṇaṃ harim // / / //
analyzed: traiguṇyāt paratas paśyet vyāptam śataguṇam harim
translated: One should see Hari, who pervades beyond the three qualities, a hundred times.

analyzed: giriśaḥ garuḍaḥ ca eva tamaḥ mātra gatam harim
translated: Shiva and Garuda see Hari as present in the mere darkness.

original: paśyed viśeṣānapi hi vāṇīdṛṣṭān na paśyati // / / //
analyzed: paśyet viśeṣān api hi vāṇī dṛṣṭān na paśyati
translated: But they do not see the distinctions seen by speech.

original: umā suparṇī ca mahattattvaṃ yāvat prapaśyati /
analyzed: umā suparṇī ca mahat tattvam yāvat prapaśyati
translated: Uma and Suparni see up to the principle of Mahat.

analyzed: rudra dṛṣṭān viśeṣān ca na eva paśyet kadācana
translated: But they never see the distinctions seen by Rudra.

analyzed: sva rūpam anya rūpam ca muktāḥ devāḥ samastaśas
translated: The liberated gods see their own form and other forms completely.

analyzed: jānanti indraḥ ca kāmaḥ ca brahma yāvat ahaṅkṛtiḥ
translated: Indra, Kama, Brahma up to the ego, knowing...

analyzed: paśyantaḥ manu dakṣa ādyāḥ buddhi tattva sthitam harim
translated: Manu, Daksha and others, seeing Hari residing in the principle of intellect,

analyzed: paśyanti soma sūryau tu mana stham parameśvaram
translated: See the supreme Lord residing in the mind, the moon and the sun...

original: anye bhūtasthitaṃ viṣṇuṃ devāḥ paśyanti sarvadā /
analyzed: anye bhūta sthitam viṣṇum devāḥ paśyanti sarvadā
translated: Other gods always see Vishnu residing in the elements.

analyzed: bahu sāhasra varṣeṇa mahat tattve kvacid kvacid
translated: Sometimes, after many thousands of years, in the principle of Mahat...

original: anye caiva yathāyogyamaṇḍāntarvartinaṃ harim /🔽śvetadvīpapatiṃ caiva hṛdyevānye tu kecana /
analyzed: anye ca eva yathāyogya maṇḍa antar vartinam harim  śvetadvīpa patim ca eva hṛdi eva anye tu kecana
translated: And others, according to their suitability, see Hari residing in the sphere of the universe.🔽Some see the Lord of Shvetadvipa only in the heart.

original: kadācideva tatrāpi kecit paśyanti keśavam // / / //🔽umā yāvadanantāṃśān pūrvadṛṣṭebhya eva tu /
analyzed: kadācid eva tatra api kecid paśyanti keśavam  umā yāvat ananta aṃśān pūrva dṛṣṭebhyaḥ eva tu
translated: Some see Keshava there also, sometimes.🔽Uma and others, after seeing the special qualities of Vasudeva from the previous parts,

analyzed: viśeṣān vāsudevasya paścāt uktāḥ vicakṣate
translated: Consider the later-mentioned parts.

analyzed: śakra kāma ādayaḥ ca eva viśeṣān brahmaṇi sthitān
translated: Shakra, Kama and others, the special qualities residing in Brahma,

analyzed: umā ādibhiḥ prabuddhebhyaḥ śata aṃśān eva cakṣate
translated: Consider them as a hundredth part of what is seen by Uma and others who are enlightened.

analyzed: ityādi veda smṛti ga vacanebhyaḥ yathārthataḥ
translated: Thus, from the statements in the Vedas and Smritis,

analyzed: tāratamyam vimuktānām sādhanānām ca dṛśyate
translated: The gradation of the liberated souls and the means of attainment is seen as it is.

analyzed: sādhya sādhana vairūpyam adṛṣṭam kena kalpyate
translated: The difference between the probandum and the means of knowledge is unseen. By whom is it imagined?

original: vaiṣamyaṃ nirghṛṇatvaṃ ca tena syātāṃ parasya ca /
analyzed: vaiṣamyam nirghṛṇa tvam ca tena syātām parasya ca
translated: And the inequality and cruelty would be of the other also.

analyzed: sāpekṣa tvāt iti ca tau vidyādhīśena vāritau
translated: And those two are refuted by the Lord of Knowledge, on the ground of dependence.

analyzed: tāratamyāt sādhanānām sādhya tādṛś tavam īśataḥ
translated: Due to the gradation of the means, the attainment of the goal is proper from the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: avaiṣamya ādi hetuḥ syāt sadā eva parameśvare
translated: The cause of non-inequality etc. would always be in the Supreme Lord.

analyzed: svātantrye vidyamāne sādhana ādau pareśituḥ
translated: Even though the Supreme Lord has independence with regard to the means etc.,

analyzed: apekṣya anādi vaicitṛyam na doṣaḥ iti tad vacaḥ
translated: he takes into account the beginningless variety. It is not a fault. That is his statement.

analyzed: na anādi tvāt iti hi uktam upapadyate iti api
translated: For it has been said that it is beginningless. It is also proper.

analyzed: apekṣya upāya vaiṣamyam upeyasya tathā sthitiḥ
translated: Taking into account the inequality of the means, the state of the goal is like that.

original: mayā kayā viruddhā syād rājādāvapi dṛśyate // / / //
analyzed: mayā kayā viruddhā syāt rāja ādau api dṛśyate
translated: By what argument is it opposed? It is seen even in the case of a king etc.

analyzed: tyāgaḥ dṛṣṭasya ca adṛṣṭa kalpanā iti su duṣkarau
translated: The abandonment of the seen and the imagination of the unseen are very difficult.

analyzed: māyibhyaḥ nyena kena api tat kim anyaiḥ ca vādibhiḥ
translated: By whom else but the Mãyãvãdins? What about the other disputants?

analyzed: tra anugamyante śruta hāni aśruta grahau
translated: The Mãyãvãdins are followed here in abandoning what is heard and accepting what is not heard.

original: apyatra māyināṃ liṅge tat ke doṣāstato 'dhikāḥ // / / //
analyzed: api atra māyinām liṅge tat ke doṣāḥ tatas dhikāḥ
translated: Even here, in the Mãyãvãdins' doctrine, what are the faults greater than that?

original: niśśeṣagatadoṣāṇāṃ bahubhirjanmabhiḥ punaḥ /🔽syādāparokṣyaṃ hi harerdveṣerṣyādistataḥ kutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: niśśeṣa gata doṣāṇām bahubhiḥ janmabhiḥ punar  syāt āparokṣyam hi hareḥ dveṣa īrṣyā ādiḥ tatas kutas
translated: For those who have completely removed faults through many births,🔽there would be the state of being in the presence of Hari. Then how can there be hatred, envy, etc.?

original: bhaveyuryadi cerṣyādyāḥ sameṣvapi kuto na te /
analyzed: bhaveyuḥ yadi ca īrṣyā ādyāḥ sameṣu api kutas na te
translated: If envy, etc. were to occur, how could they not be in those who are equal?

analyzed: tapyamānāḥ samān dṛṣṭvā dveṣa īrṣyā ādi yutāḥ api
translated: Even those who are afflicted and endowed with hatred, envy, etc.

original: dṛśyante bahavo loke doṣā evātra kāraṇam // / / //
analyzed: dṛśyante bahavaḥ loke doṣāḥ eva atra kāraṇam
translated: are seen to be many in the world. Faults alone are the cause here.

analyzed: yadi nirdoṣa tā tatra kim ādhikyena dūṣyate
translated: If there is faultlessness there, why is it criticized by superiority?

analyzed: yadi anya darśana abhāvāt īrṣyā ādiḥ vinivāryate
translated: If envy, etc. are prevented due to the absence of seeing others,

analyzed: adarśanāt arati ādiḥ katham tena nivāryate
translated: how is desire, etc. due to non-seeing prevented by that?

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ pi aratiḥ dṛṣṭvā pūrvam ekākinaḥ śrutau
translated: Even in the Vedas, it is seen that Brahman, being alone, was not pleased.

original: naiva reme sa caikākī tasamānna ramate kvacit /
analyzed: nā eva reme sa ca ekākī ramate kvacid
translated: He did not enjoy being alone. Therefore, he does not enjoy anywhere.

analyzed: dvitīyam aicchat tena asau iti śrutayaḥ ūdire
translated: He desired a second. Thus the Vedas declare.

original: yadīcchā tatra naivāstītyeva tat kalpyate mṛṣā /
analyzed: yadi icchā tatra na evā asti iti eva tat kalpyate mṛṣā
translated: If it is falsely imagined that there is no desire there at all,

analyzed: śruti ukta nirdoṣa tā eva kim nā aṅgīkriyate svayam
translated: why is not the faultlessness stated in the Vedas accepted by oneself?

original: tāratamyaṃ ca kāmaṃ ca śrutamevātihāya tu /
analyzed: tāratamyam ca kāmam ca śrutam eva atihāya tu
translated: Ignoring the stated gradation and desire,

analyzed: aśrutā samatā kena kalpyate yukti māninā
translated: How can equality, which is not heard of, be imagined by one who has reasoning?

analyzed: kim tat mānam samatve te muktānām upalabhyate
translated: What is that authority that is perceived in the case of liberated souls regarding their equality?

analyzed: vṛthā ayam āgrahaḥ kena śruta hāni aśruta grahe
translated: By whom is this useless grasping in abandoning what is heard and grasping what is not heard?

analyzed: mokṣe tāratamya itas cetana tvāt purā yathā
translated: Even in liberation, there would be gradation, because of sentience, as before.

analyzed: iti ukte uttaram kim te kalpanā mātra vādinaḥ
translated: Thus, what is your reply, O one who speaks merely of imagination?

analyzed: na ca duḥkha ādikam kalpyam nirduḥkha tva śruteḥ balāt
translated: And suffering etc. should not be imagined, because of the force of the Vedic text about being free from suffering.

analyzed: śokam tarati ātma vettā tīrṇaḥ sarvān aduḥkha bhāj
translated: The knower of the Self crosses over sorrow, being liberated, he becomes free from all suffering.

analyzed: yena ānandyā iva bhavati na śocati kadācana
translated: By whom one becomes joyful indeed, and never grieves at any time.

analyzed: kilbiṣa spṛt pitu ṣaṇiḥ aram hitaḥ iha īśvaraḥ
translated: The remover of sin, the son of Pituṣaṇa, the lord here, is well-disposed.

original: yaṃ yamantamabhiprepsuḥ sa saṅkalpād bhavediha /🔽ityādiśrutayo mānaṃ nirduḥkhatvādisampadi // / / //
analyzed: yam yam antam abhiprepsuḥ sa saṅkalpāt bhavet iha  ityādi śrutayaḥ mānam nirduḥkha tva ādi sampadi
translated: Whoever desires that particular object, he would become so by mere resolve here.🔽Thus, these Vedic texts are the authority regarding the possession of being free from suffering and so on.

analyzed: atas duḥkha ādi anumayā labhyate
translated: Therefore, there is no scope here for inferring suffering etc.

analyzed: tāratamya anumā tena bhavet na ati prasaṅginī
translated: Hence, the inference of gradation would not be too wide.

analyzed: śruti yukti balāt evam tāratamyam vibhāvyate
translated: Thus, gradation is understood by the force of the Vedic text and reasoning.

analyzed: muktau api tatas ke tra virodham kartum īśate
translated: Even in liberation, who is able to create contradiction here?

analyzed: anādi yogyatām ca eva kali vāṇī īśvara avadhim
translated: And the innate incapacity, up to the end of Kali and Vani,

analyzed: kaḥ nivārayitum śaktaḥ yukta yāgama bala uddhatām
translated: Who is able to restrain, by the power of logic and scripture, the one who is overwhelmed?

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ nyatra ādhikya yuktaḥ kālaḥ vivādavān
translated: The time that is associated with superiority other than Brahman is disputed.

analyzed: kālaḥ hi ayam yathā ityādi mānumā māninaḥ bhavet
translated: For this time, as it is said, would be the one who boasts of inference.

analyzed: anya śabdaḥ hari śrī sva samebhyaḥ
translated: The word other is used with the intention of excluding Hari, Lakshmi, and those equal to them.

original: prayukto naiva doṣāya rudrādiṣu ca yuktitaḥ // / / //
analyzed: prayuktaḥ nā eva doṣāya rudra ādiṣu ca yuktitaḥ
translated: It is not used to fault Rudra and others, who are logically superior.

original: uttamatvaṃ tu muktānāmapi na brahmaṇo bhavet /
analyzed: uttama tvam tu muktānām api na brahmaṇaḥ bhavet
translated: But even for liberated souls, there would not be superiority over Brahman.

original: vyaktiḥ sukhasya tu bhavennatvādhikyaṃ sukhasya ca // / / //
analyzed: vyaktiḥ sukhasya tu bhavet na tvā ādhikyam sukhasya ca
translated: But there would be manifestation of happiness, not superiority of happiness.

original: balajñānādhikatvaṃ ca tebhyo hi brahmaṇaḥ sadā /
analyzed: bala jñāna adhika tvam ca tebhyaḥ hi brahmaṇaḥ sadā
translated: And superiority in strength and knowledge always belongs to Brahman over them.

analyzed: ādhikyasya tu anitya tve na kiñcid mānam īyate
translated: But if superiority is not permanent, no valid means of knowledge is found.

analyzed: śṛṇve vīraḥ ugram ugram damāyan anyam anyam atinenīyamānaḥ
translated: I hear the hero, fierce and terrible, subduing one with another, being led to another.

original: edhamānadviḷubhayasya rājā coṣkūyate viśa indro manuṣyān // / / //
analyzed: rājā coṣkūyate viśaḥ indraḥ manuṣyān
translated: The king of the two who are inflamed, Indra, is urged on by the people and men.

original: parā pūrveṣāṃ sakhyā vṛṇakti vitarturāṇo aparebhireti /🔽anānubhūtīravadhūnvānaḥ pūrvītindraḥ śaradastartarīti // / / //
analyzed: parā pūrveṣām sakhyā vṛṇakti vitarturāṇaḥ aparebhiḥ eti  anānubhūtīḥ avadhūnvānaḥ pūrvīḥ indraḥ śaradaḥ tartarīti
translated: He rejects the former friendship of the earlier ones, trembling, he goes with the later ones.🔽Shaking off the unseen ones, Indra goes through the many autumns.

original: divedive sadṛśīranyamardhaṃ kṛṣṇā asedhadapa sadmano jāḥ /
analyzed: dive dive sadṛśīḥ anyam ardham kṛṣṇāḥ asedhat apa sadmanaḥ jāḥ
translated: Day by day, he drove away the black ones, the children of the house, to another half, similar ones.

original: ahan dāsā vṛṣabho vasnayantodavraje varcinaṃ śambaraṃ ca // / / //
analyzed: ahan dāsā vṛṣabhaḥ vasnayantā udavraje varcinam śambaram ca
translated: The bull killed the Dasa, the Vasnayant, in the Udvraja, Varchin and Shambara.

original: taṃ bhūtiriti devā upāsāñcakrire te babhūvustasmāddhāpyetarhi supto bhūbhrūrityeva praśvasityabhūtirityasurāste ha parābabhūvuḥ // / /🔽tad yathā peśaskarī peśaso mātrāmapādāyānyannavataraṃ kalyāṇataraṃ rūpaṃ tanuta evamevāyamātmedaṃ🔽śarīraṃ nihatyāvidyāṃ gamayitavānyannavataraṃ kalyāṇataraṃ rūpaṃ kurute pitṛyaṃ pitṛyaṃ
analyzed: tam bhūtiḥ iti devāḥ upāsāñcakrire te babhūvuḥ tasmāt ha api etarhi suptaḥ bhūbhrūḥ iti eva praśvasiti abhūtiḥ iti asurāḥ te ha parābabhūvuḥ  tat yathā peśaskarī peśasaḥ mātrām apādāya anyat navataram kalyāṇataram rūpam tanute evam eva ayam ātmā idam  śarīram nihatya avidyām gamayitavān yannavataram kalyāṇataram rūpam kurute pitṛyam pitṛyam
translated: The gods meditated upon him as Bhuti (prosperity). They became prosperous. Therefore, even now, when one sleeps, he breathes out saying Bhurbhuḥ. Abhuti (non-prosperity) is the Asuras. They indeed became defeated.

original: vā gāndharvaṃ vā daivaṃ vā prājāpatyaṃ vā brāhmaṃ vānyeṣāṃ vā bhūtānām // / / //
analyzed: vā gāndharvam vā daivam vā prājāpatyam vā brāhmam vā anyeṣām vā bhūtānām
translated: Just as a weaver, having taken a measure of thread, produces another new and better form, in the same way, this Self, having destroyed this body, having brought about ignorance, produces another new and better form, either of the fathers, or of the Gandharvas, or of the gods, or of Prajapati, or of Brahma, or of other beings.

analyzed: prayānti paramām siddhim aihika āmuṣmikīm drutam
translated: They quickly attain the highest perfection, both in this world and the next.

analyzed: yā na prāpya asuraiḥ sarvaiḥ akṣayā kleśa varjitā
translated: That imperishable state, free from all afflictions, which is not attained by all the demons,

original: na tāṃ gatiṃ prapadyante vinā bhāgavatān narān // / / //
analyzed: na tām gatim prapadyante vinā bhāgavatān narān
translated: They do not attain that state, except for human beings who are devotees of the Lord.

analyzed: avajānanti mām mūḍhāḥ mānuṣīm tanum āśritam
translated: The deluded ones disregard Me, who have taken up a human body,

original: paraṃ bhāvamajānanto mama bhūtamaheśvaram // / / //🔽moghāśā moghakarmāṇo moghajñānā vicetasaḥ /
analyzed: param bhāvam a jānantaḥ mama bhūta maheśvaram  mogha āśāḥ mogha karmāṇaḥ mogha jñānāḥ vicetasaḥ
translated: Not knowing My supreme nature as the great Lord of all beings.🔽Their desires are futile, their actions are futile, their knowledge is futile, and their minds are confused.

original: rākṣasīmāsurīṃ caiva prakṛtiṃ mohanīṃ śritāḥ // / / //🔽mahātmānastu māṃ pārtha daivīṃ prakṛtimāśritāḥ /
analyzed: rākṣasīm āsurīm ca eva prakṛtim mohanīm śritāḥ  mahātmānaḥ tu mām pārtha daivīm prakṛtim āśritāḥ
translated: They have resorted to the deluding natures of demons and Asuras.🔽But, O Partha, the great souls who have resorted to the divine nature,

analyzed: bhajanti an anya manasaḥ jñātvā bhūtādim avyayam
translated: Worship Me with one-pointed minds, knowing Me as the imperishable origin of all beings.

analyzed: abhayam sattva saṃśuddhiḥ jñāna yoga vyavasthitiḥ
translated: Fearlessness, purity of heart, wisdom, renunciation, and fortitude,

analyzed: dānam damaḥ ca yajñaḥ ca svādhyāyaḥ tapaḥ ārjavam
translated: Charity, self-control, sacrifice, study of the Vedas, austerity, and straightforwardness,

original: ahiṃsā satyamakrodhastyāgaḥ śāntirapaiśunam /🔽dayā bhūteṣvalolutvaṃ mārdavaṃ hrīracāpalam // / / //
analyzed: ahiṃsā satyam akrodhaḥ tyāgaḥ śāntiḥ apaiśunam  dayā mārdavam hrīḥ acāpalam
translated: Non-violence, truthfulness, absence of anger, renunciation, tranquility, absence of slander,🔽Compassion towards all beings, freedom from fickleness, gentleness, modesty, and absence of excitability,

analyzed: tejaḥ kṣamā dhṛtiḥ śaucam adrohaḥ na atimāni tā
translated: Radiance, forgiveness, patience, purity, absence of malice, and absence of pride,

analyzed: bhavanti sampadam daivīm abhijātasya bhārata
translated: These are the qualities of the divine nature, O son of Bharata, of one who is born noble.

analyzed: ḍambhaḥ krodhaḥ pāruṣyam eva ca
translated: Hypocrisy, arrogance, excessive pride, anger, and harshness,

analyzed: ajñānam ca abhijātasya pārtha sampadam āsurīm
translated: And ignorance, O son of Prtha, are the characteristics of the demoniacal nature.

analyzed: mām ātma para deheṣu pradviṣantaḥ bhyasūyakāḥ
translated: Those who hate, out of envy, My own Self in the bodies of others,

analyzed: tān aham dviṣataḥ krūrān saṃsāreṣu nara adhamān
translated: I cast those hateful, cruel, lowest of men into demoniacal wombs.

analyzed: kṣipāmi ajasram aśubhān āsurīṣu eva yoniṣu
translated: I constantly cast the inauspicious ones into demoniacal wombs alone.

analyzed: āsurīm yonim āpannāḥ mūḍhāḥ janmani janmani
translated: Having attained demoniacal wombs, the deluded ones, in birth after birth,

analyzed: mām a prāpya eva kaunteya tatas yānti adhamām gatim
translated: Do not attain Me, O son of Kunti, and then go to the lowest state.

original: dvividho bhūtasargo 'tra daiva āsura eva ca /
analyzed: dvividhaḥ daivaḥ āsuraḥ eva ca
translated: Here, the creation of beings is of two kinds: divine and demoniacal.

analyzed: viṣṇu bhakti paraḥ daivaḥ viparītaḥ tathā āsuraḥ
translated: One who is devoted to Vishnu is divine, and the opposite is demoniacal.

original: devānāṃ paramo dharmaḥ sadā yajñādikāḥ kriyāḥ /
analyzed: devānām paramaḥ dharmaḥ sadā yajña ādikāḥ kriyāḥ
translated: The highest duty of the gods is always the performance of sacrifices and other rites,

analyzed: svādhyāyaḥ tattva vedi tvam viṣṇu pūjā ratiḥ smṛtiḥ
translated: Study of one's own scriptures, knowledge of reality, and the remembrance of devotion to Vishnu.

original: daityānāṃ bāhuṣāḷitvaṃ mātsaryaṃ yuddhasatkriyā /🔽nītiśāstrapraveditvaṃ śivapūjāratiḥ smṛtiḥ // / / //
analyzed: daityānām bāhuṣāḷi tvam mātsaryam yuddha satkriyā  nīti śāstra pravedi tvam śiva pūjā ratiḥ smṛtiḥ
translated: For the demons, it is boasting with the arms, jealousy, honoring battles,🔽Knowledge of the science of politics, and the remembrance of devotion to Shiva.

analyzed: varṇa āśrama ācāravat tvam svādhyāyaḥ bhaktiḥ acyute
translated: For the Brahmanas, it is following the duties of one's own caste and stage of life, studying one's own scriptures, and devotion to Achyuta (Vishnu).

original: śive sūrye tathā devyāṃ svabhāvo mānuṣaḥ smṛtaḥ // / / //🔽anādivaiṣṇavā eva devatāstu svabhāvataḥ /
analyzed: śive sūrye tathā devyām svabhāvaḥ mānuṣaḥ smṛtaḥ  anādi vaiṣṇavāḥ eva devatāḥ tu svabhāvataḥ
translated: In Shiva, the Sun, and the Goddess, the human nature is remembered as natural.🔽The deities are indeed naturally Vaishnavas from the beginning.

analyzed: viparītāḥ tatas daityāḥ sadā eva anādi kālataḥ
translated: The demons are the opposite from that, always from the beginning.

analyzed: mānuṣāḥ miśra matayaḥ vimiśra gatayaḥ pi ca
translated: Humans have mixed thoughts and mixed conduct.

analyzed: ityādi vākya sandarbhe jñāyate na ādi yogyatā
translated: Thus, from the collection of statements like this, the beginningless eligibility is known.

analyzed: yadi anādiḥ viśeṣaḥ na sāmpratam katham eva saḥ
translated: If the beginningless distinction is not present now, how can it be?

analyzed: adṛṣṭāt eva ca adṛṣṭam svīkṛtam savarvādibhiḥ
translated: The beginningless has been accepted by all from the unseen itself.

analyzed: ākasmikaḥ viśeṣaḥ ced adṛṣṭe kvacid iṣyate
translated: If a sudden distinction is accepted in some unseen [case],

original: sarvatrākasmikatvaṃ syānnādṛṣṭāpekṣatā bhavet /🔽adṛṣṭāśced viśeṣo 'yamanāditvaṃ kuto na tat // / / //
analyzed: sarvatra ākasmika tvam syāt na adṛṣṭa apekṣa tā bhavet  adṛṣṭāḥ ced viśeṣaḥ yama nādi tvam kutas na tat
translated: suddenness would be in everything, and dependence on the unseen would not be.🔽If this distinction is unseen, why is it not beginningless?

analyzed: na ca anya bheda vat viṣṇau bhedaḥ tad darśinām api
translated: Even for those who see Vishnu as different from others, the difference is not seen.

analyzed: dṛśyate pratyabhijñā eva bahu rūpeṣu dṛśyate
translated: Recognition itself is seen in many forms.

original: bahutvaṃ ca viśeṣeṇa na bhedena kathañcana /
analyzed: bahu tvam ca viśeṣeṇa na bhedena kathañcana
translated: And multiplicity is by no means by difference.

original: pratyabhijñā ca yeṣāṃ na te 'pi tanmuṣyadṛṣṭayaḥ // / / //
analyzed: pratyabhijñā ca yeṣām na te tad muṣya dṛṣṭayaḥ
translated: And those for whom there is recognition are not even those whose vision is obstructed by that.

original: bhedaṃ naiva prapaśyanti bhedamanyebhya eva ca /
analyzed: bhedam nā eva prapaśyanti bhedam anyebhyaḥ eva ca
translated: They do not see any difference, and others see only differences.

analyzed: paśyanti evam hariḥ teṣām sandarśayati nā anyathā
translated: In this way, Hari shows them, not otherwise.

analyzed: evam bṛhatsaṃhitāyām vacanam na purāṇa gam
translated: Thus, the statement in the Bṛhatsaṃhitā is not found in the Purāṇas.

analyzed: loka darśana vādī eva veda rodhāya śaknuyāt
translated: One who merely advocates the view of the world could not refute the Vedas.

analyzed: a parīkṣita dṛṣṭiḥ ca parīkṣā pūrva darśanam
translated: And one whose view is not examined could refute the view preceded by examination.

analyzed: niṣeddhum śaknuvādi eva veda rodhāya śaknuyāt
translated: Only one who can refute could refute the Vedas.

analyzed: na ca niścita bhedasya darśane sti purāṇa gam
translated: And there is no statement in the Purāṇas regarding the vision of one whose difference is ascertained.

analyzed: vākyam kvacid hi sammugdha darśanam tatra gamyate
translated: For somewhere a confused vision is understood there.

analyzed: aparīkṣitam eva atra vedha ādikam adhīśituḥ
translated: Here, the creation etc. of the Lord is not examined.

analyzed: parīkṣā darśane nā eva dṛśyate kenacid kvacid
translated: In the view of examination, it is not seen by anyone anywhere.

analyzed: nirdoṣam eva tam brahmā dadarśa aśeṣa rūpiṇam
translated: Brahmā saw him, who is faultless and has all forms.

analyzed: nirdoṣam eva rudraḥ drāk nirdoṣam tam purandaraḥ
translated: Rudra saw him as faultless, and Purandara saw him as faultless.

analyzed: nirdoṣāṇi asya rūpāṇi dṛṣṭāni evam sura uttamaiḥ
translated: The faultless forms of him are thus seen by the best gods.

analyzed: anye sa doṣāḥ sarve nirdoṣaḥ hariḥ ekalaḥ
translated: Others are all faulty, but Hari alone is faultless.

original: iti barkuśruteścaiva sadoṣaṃ nāsya darśanam // / / //🔽aviddho viddhavad viṣṇurajāto jātavanmṛṣā /
analyzed: iti barku śruteḥ ca eva sa doṣam na asya darśanam  a viddhaḥ viddha vat viṣṇuḥ a jātaḥ jāta vat mṛṣā
translated: And also because of the Barku Shruti, His vision is not faulty.🔽Vishnu, though undivided, displays Himself as if divided, though unborn, as if born, falsely,

analyzed: abaddhaḥ baddha vat ca eva darśayati amita dyutiḥ
translated: and though unbound, as if bound. The one of infinite splendor.

original: iti paiṅgiśrutiścaiva prāha nirdoṣatāṃ hareḥ // / / //🔽aparīkṣitadṛṣṭayaiva sadoṣo dṛśyate hariḥ /
analyzed: iti paiṅgi śrutiḥ ca eva prāha nirdoṣa tām hareḥ  aparīkṣita dṛṣṭayā eva sa doṣaḥ dṛśyate hariḥ
translated: Thus the Pingala Shruti also declares the faultlessness of Hari.🔽Hari is seen to be faulty only by the unexamined eye.

original: parīkṣādarśane naiva dṛśyo doṣo hareḥ kvacit /
analyzed: parīkṣā darśane nā eva dṛśyaḥ doṣaḥ hareḥ kvacid
translated: But when examined, no fault is seen anywhere in Hari.

analyzed: iti paiṅgi śrutiḥ ca āha pramāṇam hi parīkṣitam
translated: Thus the Pingala Shruti says that a valid means of knowledge is indeed examined.

analyzed: na parīkṣā anavasthā syāt sākṣi siddhe tu asaṃśayāt
translated: There would be no infinite regress of examination, because of the undoubted establishment by the witness.

analyzed: mānase darśane doṣāḥ syuḥ na vai sākṣi darśane
translated: Faults may occur in mental perception, but not in witness perception.

original: sudṛḍho nirṇayo yatra jñeyaṃ tat sākṣidarśanam // / / //
analyzed: su dṛḍhaḥ nirṇayaḥ yatra jñeyam tat sākṣi darśanam
translated: That which is well-established is to be known as witness perception.

analyzed: icchā jñānam sukham duḥkha bhaya abhaya kṛpā ādayaḥ
translated: Desire, knowledge, pleasure, pain, fear, fearlessness, compassion, etc.

original: sākṣisiddhā na kaściddhi tatra saṃśayavān kvacit /🔽yat kvacid vyabhicārī syād darśanaṃ mānasaṃ hi tat // / / //
analyzed: sākṣi siddhāḥ na kaścid hi tatra saṃśayavān kvacid  yat kvacid vyabhicārī syāt darśanam mānasam hi tat
translated: Are established by the witness. No one has any doubt about them anywhere.🔽Where there would be error somewhere, that is indeed mental perception.

analyzed: manaḥ cakṣuḥ darśana ādeḥ api yatra eva sākṣiṇā
translated: Even where there is doubt about the perception of the mind, the eye, and so on,

analyzed: prāmāṇyam su gṛhītam syāt tat parīkṣita darśanam
translated: That which has been tested by experience is well-established as valid.

analyzed: na jñāna dṛṣṭi mātreṇa prāmāṇyam tasya dṛśyate
translated: The validity of that [cognition] is not seen merely by the vision of knowledge.

analyzed: niyamena sukha ādyeṣu prāmāṇyam sākṣi gocaram
translated: The validity of pleasure, etc. is invariably the domain of the witness.

analyzed: sva prāmāṇyam sadā sākṣī paśyati eva su niścayāt
translated: The witness always sees its own validity with certainty.

original: jñānasya grāhakeṇaiva sākṣiṇā mānatāmiteḥ // / / //🔽doṣābhāve pramāṇatvaṃ doṣābhāvasya sākṣiṇā /
analyzed: jñānasya grāhakeṇa eva sākṣiṇā māna tā miteḥ  doṣa abhāve pramāṇa tvam doṣa abhāvasya sākṣiṇā
translated: Because the validity of knowledge is determined by the witness, which is the apprehender of that [knowledge].🔽The absence of defects in the validity of the witness,

analyzed: niścita tvam kvacid ca eva svatas prāmāṇyam iṣyate
translated: and the certainty of the absence of defects in some cases, is accepted as self-validity.

original: ato na sarvamānānāṃ prāmāṇyaṃ niścitaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: atas na sarva mānānām prāmāṇyam niścitam bhavet
translated: Therefore, the validity of all means of knowledge would not be ascertained.

original: sākṣiṇā niścitaṃ yatra tat prāmāṇyasvalakṣaṇam // / / //🔽na hi kaścit sukhādyeṣu saṃśayaṃ kurute janaḥ /
analyzed: sākṣiṇā niścitam yatra tat prāmāṇya sva lakṣaṇam  na hi kaścid sukha ādyeṣu saṃśayam kurute janaḥ
translated: Where it is ascertained by the witness, that is the specific characteristic of validity.🔽For no one entertains doubt regarding pleasure, etc.

analyzed: na ca eva akhila mānāni niścinoti akhilaḥ janaḥ
translated: And not all people ascertain all means of knowledge.

analyzed: tasmāt anubhava ārūḍham kimartham upalapyate
translated: Therefore, what is established by experience, why is it spoken of?

analyzed: doṣa abhāva ādikam ca eva sākṣī samyak prapaśyati
translated: And the witness clearly sees the absence of defects, etc.

original: tat parīkṣitamānena na doṣo viṣṇavi kvacit /
analyzed: tat parīkṣita mānena na doṣaḥ viṣṇavi kvacid
translated: By that which has been tested by means of knowledge, there is no defect anywhere in Viṣṇu.

analyzed: aparīkṣita dṛṣṭiḥ tu kasmin arthe na vidyate
translated: But an unexamined view exists in regard to what object?

analyzed: tat pratyakṣa viruddha arthe na āgamasya api māna tā
translated: In a matter contrary to perception, even scripture is not valid.

analyzed: upajīvyam akṣa jam yatra tat anyatra viparyayaḥ
translated: Where perception is relied upon, it is reversed elsewhere.

analyzed: laukike vyavahāre tra pratyakṣasya upajīvya tā  avatāra ādi daṣṭau syāt āgamasya upajīvya tā
translated: In this worldly usage, perception is relied upon.🔽In the case of the manifestation of Vishnu, etc., scripture is relied upon.

original: āgamena hi viṣṇutvaṃ jñātvā doṣo 'tra kalpyate /
analyzed: āgamena hi viṣṇu tvam jñātvā kalpyate
translated: For, having known Vishnuhood by scripture, a fault is imagined here.

original: na cet syāt doṣavānanyaḥ śāstrasiddhaṃ hi lakṣaṇam // / / //
analyzed: na ced syāt doṣavān anyaḥ śāstra siddham hi lakṣaṇam
translated: If it were not so, another would be faulty, for the definition is established by scripture.

analyzed: kasyacid doṣavat tvam syāt iti mātre kṣajam bhavet
translated: The perception would be mere that some one would be faulty.

original: na viṣṇordeṣavattve hi pratyakṣaṃ vartate svataḥ // / / //
analyzed: na viṣṇoḥ deṣavat tve hi pratyakṣam vartate svatas
translated: For, perception does not operate by itself in the case of Vishnu's being faulty.

analyzed: kecid paśyanti doṣān iti atra api syāt na ca akṣajam
translated: Even in the case of some seeing faults, it would not be perception.

analyzed: paurāṇam vākyam evā atra tad śrutyā eva viruddhayate
translated: Here, the statement of the Puranas is contradicted by the Vedas themselves.

analyzed: purāṇasya upajīvyaḥ ca vedaḥ eva na ca aparaḥ
translated: And the Vedas alone are relied upon by the Puranas, not another.

original: tadvirodhe kathaṃ mānaṃ tat tatra ca bhaviṣyati // / / //
analyzed: tad virodhe katham mānam tat tatra ca bhaviṣyati
translated: How can that be valid in that case, when there is contradiction with them?

analyzed: aparīkṣita dṛṣṭiḥ ca katham evā akṣa jam bhavet
translated: And how can an unexamined view be perception?

analyzed: yadi evam devadatta ādi bhramaḥ kim nā akṣa jam bhavet
translated: If it is so, why should not the illusion of Devadatta etc. be born of the senses?

analyzed: yāvacchakti parīkṣāyām upajīvyasya bādhane
translated: In the examination up to the utmost of one's power, if the sublated is the object of dependence,

analyzed: doṣaḥ na a śodhite doṣaḥ upajīvya tvam asu alam
translated: there is a fault. If it is not purified, the fault is that dependence is not sufficient.

analyzed: bhrame sti tad mātram upajīvya hi
translated: Even in illusion, there is a part that is not illusion. Only that is the object of dependence.

analyzed: bādhaka jñāna vṛttiḥ syāt na ca evam su parīkṣite
translated: The occurrence of the sublating cognition would not be so in what is well examined.

analyzed: sarvam tat upajīvya eva pramāṇam vartate yatas
translated: Because all that is the means of valid knowledge operates only in dependence on that.

analyzed: katham brahma iti tat jñeyam sarvajña tva ādi lakṣaṇam
translated: How is Brahman to be known? By its characteristics such as omniscience etc.

analyzed: vihāya yasmāt kasmāt cit svarūpasya eva ced yadi
translated: If it is only of its own nature, without anything else,

analyzed: upajīvya tvam etasmāt vyāvṛttam yāvatā bhavet
translated: to that extent, dependence would be excluded.

analyzed: tāvatā eva upajīvya tvam svarapasya eva na kvacid
translated: To that extent, dependence is only on its own nature, not anywhere else.

analyzed: sarva lakṣaṇa yuktam tu svarūpam yadi bhaṇyate
translated: But if the nature endowed with all characteristics is stated,

original: astu no naiva hāniḥ syāt svapakṣaścāyamañjasā // / / //
analyzed: astu naḥ nā eva hāniḥ syāt sva pakṣaḥ ca ayam añjasā
translated: let it be so. There would be no loss for us, and this position of ours would be straightforward.

analyzed: yasmāt anvitaḥ eva arthaḥ śabdānām api sarvaśas
translated: Because the object is only related to the words in every way,

analyzed: viśeṣa sāmanya tayā svarūpam akhilam bhavet
translated: the entire nature would be by way of particular and general.

analyzed: purovarti tva pūrvāṇi devadatta ādika bhrame
translated: In the illusion of Devadatta and so on, the prior states of being in front

analyzed: vyāvartayanti tad rūpam vinā eva hi
translated: do indeed turn away from that form, merely from Caitra without any other reason.

analyzed: brahmaṇaḥ nirviśeṣa tvāt vyāvartayati kim punar
translated: How then does it turn away from Brahman, due to its being without distinctions?

analyzed: yasmāt kasmāccid api arthāt tāvat ced siddha sādhanam
translated: If it is established merely to that extent, from some object or other, then the proof is superfluous.

analyzed: cit mātra tvam ca na eva iṣyam aviśeṣa tva vādinaḥ
translated: And the state of being mere consciousness is not accepted by one who advocates non-distinction.

original: tāvanmātraṃ yadīṣyaṃ syāt sarvajñatvaṃ kuto na tat // / / //
analyzed: tāvanmātram yadi iṣyam syāt sarvajña tvam kutas na tat
translated: If that much were to be accepted, then why not omniscience?

analyzed: cit mātra abheda sādhye siddham tat prativādinaḥ
translated: Even in what is to be accomplished by the non-distinction of mere consciousness, that is established for the opponent.

original: svābhedāṅgīkṛtereva cittvaṃ svasyāpi yanmatam // / / //🔽sarvāpekṣatayā sarvajñatvamityeva tannahi /
analyzed: sva abheda aṅgīkṛteḥ eva cit tvam svasya api yat matam  sarva apekṣa tayā sarvajña tvam iti eva tat na hi
translated: Because of the acceptance of one's own non-distinction, consciousness is also what is considered by oneself.🔽If it is said that omniscience is due to the dependence on everything, then that is not so.

original: iti ceccetanatvaṃ ca jñatvaṃ na jñeyavarjitam // / / //
analyzed: iti ced cetana tvam ca jña tvam na jñeya varjitam
translated: If it is said that consciousness is not knowledge devoid of the knowable,

analyzed: sva jñeya tvam ca nā eva asau manyate sa viśeṣataḥ
translated: then it is not accepted that it is its own knowable, especially.

analyzed: sva śabdaḥ pi para apekṣaḥ tasmāt vyāvṛttiḥ eva hi
translated: The word 'svayam' (itself) also depends on another. Therefore, it is indeed exclusion.

original: svaśabdārtha iti proktaḥ svarūpaṃ nāma kiṃ na cet // / / //
analyzed: sva śabda arthaḥ iti proktaḥ svarūpam nāma kim na ced
translated: Is it not said that the meaning of the word 'svayam' (itself) is the form (of Brahman), which is called its own nature?

analyzed: rūpa śabdena pūrṇa tvāt tat ca sāmānya tā vacaḥ
translated: Due to the word 'rūpa' (form) denoting completeness, and that is a word denoting generality,

original: na svarūpābhidhāyi syād vaiyarthyaṃ svaravasya yat // / / //
analyzed: na sva rūpa abhidhāyi syāt vaiyarthyam sva ravasya yat
translated: It would not express the nature of the self, because the syllable 'svā' would be meaningless.

analyzed: cetanasya svabhāvaḥ hi caitanyam iti gīyate
translated: The nature of the conscious being is said to be consciousness.

original: tasmād viśeṣabāhulyaṃ caitanyasya viśeṣataḥ // / / //🔽na jñeyajñātṛhīnaṃ hi jñānaṃ nāma kvacid bhavet /
analyzed: tasmāt viśeṣa bāhulyam caitanyasya viśeṣataḥ  na jñeya jñātṛ hīnam hi jñānam nāma kvacid bhavet
translated: Therefore, consciousness is especially distinguished by the abundance of particularities.🔽Knowledge cannot exist anywhere without the known and the knower.

original: jñeyajñānavihīnaśca jña ityatra ca na pramā // / / //🔽jñātṛjñeyavihīnaṃ ca jñānaṃ ced bhoktṛbhojyataḥ /
analyzed: jñeya jñāna vihīnaḥ ca jñaḥ iti atra ca na pramā  jñātṛ jñeya vihīnam ca jñānam ced bhoktṛ bhojyataḥ
translated: And without the known and the knowledge, there is no valid cognition of the knower.🔽If knowledge is devoid of the knower and the known, then eating would be devoid of the eater and the food,

original: hīnaṃ bhojanameva syāt tāḍanaṃ kartṛtāḍyataḥ // / / //🔽nityatvāt tādṛśaṃ ca syāditi cennityavāgapi /
analyzed: hīnam bhojanam eva syāt tāḍanam kartṛ tāḍyataḥ  nitya tvāt tādṛśam ca syāt iti ced nitya vāc api
translated: and beating would be devoid of the agent and the object to be beaten.🔽If it is argued that it would be like that because of eternality, it is not so, because even eternal speech

analyzed: vācya vaktṛ vihīnā syāt na hi sā ca eva tādṛśī
translated: would be devoid of the speaker and the spoken, for it is not like that.

original: draṣṭāro vedavāco hi santi vācyāni cāñjasā /
analyzed: draṣṭāraḥ veda vācaḥ hi santi vācyāni ca añjasā
translated: The hearers of the Vedic statements and the directly expressible meanings

original: nityo draṣṭā ca vācyaśca bhagavāneva ca svayam // / / //
analyzed: nityaḥ draṣṭā ca vācyaḥ ca bhagavān eva ca svayam
translated: are the eternal seer and the expressible one, the Lord Himself.

original: na hi vaktṛvihīnā ca vācyahīnāpi vāk kvacit /
analyzed: na hi vaktṛ vihīnā ca vācya hīnā api vāc kvacid
translated: For nowhere is speech devoid of the speaker or devoid of the spoken,

original: jñātṛjñeyavihīnaṃ ca jñānamevaṃ na tad bhavet // / / //
analyzed: jñātṛ jñeya vihīnam ca jñānam evam na tat bhavet
translated: and knowledge would not be like that, devoid of the knower and the known.

analyzed: na hi vaktā asti vākya vācya vivarjitaḥ
translated: For even the eternal speaker is not devoid of the sentence and the spoken.

analyzed: jñāna jñeya vihīnaḥ ca pi evam na eva vidyate
translated: And the knower also, devoid of knowledge and the knowable, does not exist in this way.

analyzed: kiñca sarva vilopaḥ ca kena mānena gamyate
translated: Moreover, how is the denial of everything known?

original: sarveṇa saha tad vākyāmarthaśca yadi gṛhyate /
analyzed: sarveṇa saha tat vākyām arthaḥ ca yadi gṛhyate
translated: If the meaning of that statement is grasped along with everything,

analyzed: tad abhāvena sarvasya na apalāpaḥ bhavet tadā
translated: then the denial of everything would not be possible at that time.

original: na gṛhyate ced tannyāyādapalāpo na hi kvacit /
analyzed: na gṛhyate ced tad nyāyāt apalāpaḥ na hi kvacid
translated: If it is not grasped, then there is no denial anywhere due to that reason.

analyzed: upapatti vihīnasya vākyasya arthaḥ na gamyate
translated: The meaning of a statement devoid of reasoning is not understood.

analyzed: upakrama ādi liṅgānām balīyaḥ hi uttarottaram
translated: The later are stronger than the earlier indications such as context, etc.

original: śrutyādau pūrvapūrvaṃ ca brahmatarkavinirṇayāt // / / //🔽pratyakṣamupapattiśca bahavaścāgamā yadā /
analyzed: śruti ādau pūrva pūrvam ca brahma tarka vinirṇayāt  pratyakṣam upapattiḥ ca bahavaḥ ca āgamāḥ yadā
translated: And the earlier are stronger than Śruti, etc., as determined by Brahma Tarka.

analyzed: viruddha yante na ca arthaḥ sti yatra liṅga virodhi tā
translated: When perception, reasoning, and many scriptures contradict, and there is no meaning where there is contradiction of indications,

analyzed: saḥ eva arthaḥ katham grāhyaḥ upapanne virodhinī
translated: how can that very meaning be accepted, when there is no contradiction?

original: mukhyārthe vidyamāne tu kva sāvarjñyaṃ niṣiddhayate // / / //
analyzed: mukhya arthe vidyamāne tu kva sāvarjñyam
translated: When the primary meaning exists, where is the denial of the plurality of meanings?

analyzed: atas sarva guṇaiḥ yuktam brahma aṅgīkā yarma eva hi
translated: Therefore, Brahman alone, endowed with all qualities, should be accepted.

analyzed: apalāpaḥ pi sarvasya na kathañcana yujyate
translated: The denial of everything is not possible in any way.

analyzed: anādi yogyatā ca uktā tena grāhyā eva sarvathā
translated: Therefore, the innate capacity of the individual souls is accepted in all respects.

analyzed: muktānām tāratamyam ca mānaiḥ uktaiḥ na cālyate
translated: And the gradation among the liberated souls cannot be shaken by the proofs stated.

original: jñānino 'pi yato nityaṃ kurvanti śubhameva hi /
analyzed: jñāninaḥ yatas nityam kurvanti śubham eva hi
translated: Because the wise ones always perform only good deeds,

analyzed: tāratamyam tu muktau ca tena eva adhyavasīyate
translated: Therefore, the gradation is ascertained even in liberation.

original: tāratamyaṃ na cenmuktau kutaḥ kuryuḥ śubhaṃ punaḥ /
analyzed: tāratamyam na ced muktau kutas kuryuḥ śubham punar
translated: If there were no gradation in liberation, why would they again perform good deeds?

original: kṛcchreṇāpi tapo jñānaṃ karmāpyete caranti hi // / / //
analyzed: kṛcchreṇa api tapaḥ jñānam karma api ete caranti hi
translated: They perform austerities, knowledge, and even rituals with difficulty.

analyzed: bibhyati sma aśubhāt nityam sa kāmāḥ ca śubhe sadā
translated: They are always afraid of evil and always desire good.

analyzed: na ca svabhāvaḥ eva ayam bhaya pūrva pravṛttitaḥ
translated: And this is not their natural disposition, because they engage in activities preceded by fear,

analyzed: kṛcchreṇa ācaraṇāt ca eva śubhasya eva punar punar
translated: And because they perform good deeds again and again with difficulty.

analyzed: svabhāvaḥ ced ajñasya api bhavet tathā
translated: If such were their natural disposition, it would be the same for the ignorant as well.

original: phalavattve pramāṇaṃ cet tatra jñasya samaṃ hi tat // / / //
analyzed: phalavat tve pramāṇam ced tatra jñasya samam hi tat
translated: If the proof is in the presence of results, then that is the same for the wise.

analyzed: niṣkāmam jñāna pūrvam ca nivṛttam iha ca ucyate
translated: That which is performed without desire and preceded by knowledge is said to be nivṛtta here.

analyzed: nivṛttam sevamānaḥ tu brahma abhyeti sanātanam
translated: By serving the nivṛtta, one attains the eternal Brahman.

analyzed: syāt ghrāsaḥ ca eva aśubhena hi
translated: By good, there is an increase in bliss, and by evil, there is a decrease.

analyzed: yatas tena kartavyam śubham eva taiḥ
translated: Therefore, even the wise ones should perform only good deeds.

original: upāste sa ya ātmānaṃ kṣīyate nāsya karma ha /
analyzed: upāste sa yaḥ ātmānam kṣīyate na asya karma ha
translated: He who worships the Self, his actions do not perish.

original: asmāddhayevātmano yadyat kāmayet sṛjate ca tat // / / //
analyzed: asmāt ha yā iva ātmanaḥ yat yat kāmayet sṛjate ca tat
translated: From this very Self, whatever one desires and creates, that alone...

analyzed: a vidvān bahu karmā api hi antavat phalam āpnuyāt
translated: Even an ignorant person with many actions would obtain limited fruits.

analyzed: yat eva vidyayā kuryāt tat eva hi ati vīryavat
translated: Whatever one does with knowledge, that alone becomes extremely powerful.

analyzed: ityādi vākya sāmarthyāt tāratamyam vimukti gam  na ca atra upāsakasya eva phalam akṣayam ucyate
translated: By the power of statements like these, there is gradation in liberation...🔽And here, the inexhaustible fruit is not said to belong only to the worshipper.

original: na hi jñānaṃ vinā kvāpi phalasyākṣayatā bhavet /🔽jñānadvāreṇa cet tasya nāsmatpakṣapratīpatā // / / //
analyzed: na hi jñānam vinā kvāpi phalasya akṣaya tā bhavet  jñāna dvāreṇa ced tasya na asmad pakṣa pratīpa tā
translated: For without knowledge, the fruit can never be inexhaustible anywhere.🔽If it is through the door of knowledge, then it does not contradict our position...

original: jñānottarasyaivamapi hyakṣayatvaṃ nacānyathā /🔽pūrvabhāviśubhānāṃ hi jñānenaiva kṛtārthatā // / / //
analyzed: jñāna uttarasya evam api hi akṣaya tvam na ca anyathā  pūrva bhāvi śubhānām hi jñānena eva kṛtārtha tā
translated: For even then, the inexhaustible nature belongs only to one who has knowledge, not otherwise.🔽For the previous auspicious actions become fruitful only through knowledge...

analyzed: prārabdhānām tu bhogena tad jñāna uttara karmaṇām
translated: But for the actions begun and experienced, which are subsequent to that knowledge,

analyzed: muktau anupraveśaḥ syāt anyathā tad kṛtiḥ na hi
translated: there would be entry into liberation, otherwise those actions would not be performed...

analyzed: jñānāt pūrvāṇi sarvāṇi śubhāni jñāna siddhaye
translated: All the previous auspicious actions are for the accomplishment of knowledge.

analyzed: akāmyāni niṣiddhāni jñāna rodhāya bhuktaye
translated: The undesirable and prohibited acts are for the obstruction of knowledge and enjoyment.

analyzed: yogya tāyāḥ balāt yat ca śubha bāhulyam āditas
translated: And because of the power of eligibility, one should first do the abundance of good deeds,

analyzed: jñāna bāhulyam eva etat kuryāt na anyasya kāraṇam
translated: which is nothing but the abundance of knowledge, not the cause of anything else.

analyzed: jñānasya bhakti bhāga tvāt bhaktiḥ jñānam iti īryate
translated: Because of the part of devotion in knowledge, devotion is said to be knowledge.

analyzed: jñānasya eva viśeṣaḥ yat bhaktiḥ iti abhidhīyate
translated: The special quality of knowledge itself is called devotion.

analyzed: parokṣa tva aparokṣa tve viśeṣau jñāna gau yathā
translated: Just as the special qualities of knowledge are the states of being imperceptible and perceptible,
